item.title: Conversations with God - Part 1 (Grace)
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
I'm going to attempt to share something online that is somewhat personal and could potentially be offensive, but on the flip side could be very potent and life-giving. I believe God speaks to us today and I am going to release one of my conversations with Him, one that addresses you! If you object to something I say, please be gentle about it since I am in a humble place with sharing this. I do not mean to be proud or claim to hear God perfectly accurately if it may be not. (This is what I felt like the Lord was saying. It may not all be Him, I may have heard some things incorrectly. So if you will, give me grace for hearing incorrectly and use discernment as you read this for your own sake. Words without quotations are my words. Words with "quotations" are God's words. God bless!) Context: (I had read a few of my conversations with the Lord to people and 3 of them encouraged me to turn it into a book. As I was pondering it, I came across the question... If these are God's words, is it ok to edit them? Or should I just leave everything raw.) So you think I should just edit these conversations? “Unless you want to share everything with the world. When you are writing to the world, remember you are not writing to Me. The world will not like everything you say, but if they are reading your book, then they will have an open mind. That being said, I can start a new series of conversations for you called conversations for the world.”

O God! I would love that! So the rule is, I have to keep personal stuff somewhat aside and talk to you as if the world is listening.

“And I will do the same. I will try not to embarrass you too much or get you into too much trouble.”

Thanks God. So that leads to this question. If the world could ask you anything what would they ask you? There are many questions. Which do you think is primary or most important?

“The issue of faith. Many Christians are doubting their salvation because they have put trust in their works rather than the solid foundation of the cross. You know I have taught you how to understand and interpret the scripture but there are many who have not heard the sincerity of the good news. So our first conversation will be about Grace.”

Ok God, I'm going to play the role of the world and take on a worldly perspective and I ask that you would speak to me as if not to me, but as if to the world.

What is Grace?

What is grace?

“Unmerited favor. Unconditional love. It is my generosity shown towards you in lovingkindness according to my willingness to give, not according to your striving to get it.”

Who do you give your grace to?

“To the undeserving.”

That would make sense, 'unmerited'. But aren't there some qualifications to receiving your favor? I mean, if we all had all your favor wouldn't we be seeing miracles all the time?

“Who says your not? But your question is valid. Who do I give my grace to?”

The underserving.

“The undeserving and the ungodly. So who has a hard time receiving my grace?”

The self-righteous. Those who deserve it, or more specifically think they've earned it.

“I tell you the truth, as long as you are trying to earn my favor through your behavior the promises will escape you and your behavior will fail.”

But don't you reward good?

“Yes, righteousness brings a reward but that reward is not your inheritance. 'But to him who does not work, but trusts God who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness.'”

Then if we are blessed by faith, how do you reward works?

“Consider one of your own children. Would you withhold a good thing from that child because he did not earn it? You may, being evil, but your heavenly father knows how to give good gifts to his children. In the same way, would you not reward the good he does to show your pride in him and to encourage that behavior? I tell you many parents would do so all the time if they could, but your heavenly father rewards richly.”

So then how is the opposite of that read?

“To the one who does not deserve it?”

Yes.

“My grace is sufficient for Him. 'But to him who does not work, but trusts God who justifies the ungodly, his faith is credited as righteousness.' What his works could not do, his faith can.”

I can already hear some pastors asking wouldn't that make us lazy?

“'Come to me all who are weary and burnt out on religion and I will give you rest.' 'Let us therefore strive to enter that rest, so that no one may fall by the same sort of disobedience.' What one man calls lazy I call burnt out. But in that case I may have a thing or to to say to the one who barking, 'Lazy! Lazy!' Perhaps he is standing on shaky ground. I tell you, it is not good for one man, however confident in his abilities to put confident in his flesh. He will fall harder than any.”

So I take it its not appropriate to say that by resting we are being lazy.

“You have switched topics. You are asking if the Lord encourages laziness. No. Man finds life in work. There is no need to conclude from what I said that a man should practice laziness.”

Some people may be surprised that I'm taking to you so casually, they may wonder if its even You talking with me.

“If you don't want to share this conversation that's fine. Be content knowing that you understand and believe, and do not let your faith waver because of everyone's opinion. But, they do understand this comes from me, if not by the words I said, by the scriptures I referenced.”

We may need more of those.

“Men seeks consolation in a multitude of verses, but one can contain the message of many. I don't want you to have to type as many verses as I could give you.

Do you feel like this topic is sufficiently covered?

“We will come back to it. But we can start on something else.”

item.title: Conversations with God - Part 2 Why is there pain?
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
If you haven't read Conversations with God - Part 1, I encourage you to do that. Some of these conversations are in context and in order for a reason. Keep in mind while you read that even though I often hear God's voice, occasionally I mishear or unintentionally discern one of my own thoughts as being from Him. I just ask God a question and pretty much write down whatever comes to mind. So just as I do, use discernment and give me grace to make mistakes while you read! Thanks. O! And be gentle with the comments, this is a fairly humble and vulnerable position for me. In using discernment, one of the ways the Holy Spirit speaks is by giving us peace about a certain topic. If you are reading this and you feel troubled or you are not finding peace, reject it, no matter how smooth it may be.

If God is sovereign, why is their pain?

Here is a popular question I can imagine many people asking. If God is Lord of all, why is there pain in the earth? Why is there sickness?

“If a father is good why do his children get sick? Because those children make choices apart from the will of the father. Being Lord of all does not mean I get my will all the time. I promise life, and I fulfill that. And as you have realized, my promises don't end there, I have promised to bless you in every way. But the blessings I give you here pale compared to the blessings I will give you in eternity.”

So why can you not get your will all the time?

“Because I need people who desire my will. When a person agrees with my will, then it will be accomplished in his life, no matter how impossible it may seem. Apart from the will of the father, you can do nothing.”

So you're saying I need to have a heart that rejoices in your will?

“Delight in the Lord and He will give you the desires of your heart. A famous man wrote that.”

How can I tell if I'm agreeing with the will of God or walking opposed to it?

“My spirit in you is the biggest indicator. It is not my will to bring pain. Nor sickness. Nor death. I came to set the captives free.”

You said something earlier that startled me. You need us to desire your will for your will to be done? Why can you not force it upon us?

“Why can you not force a child to eat his vegetables? As soon as I start forcing my will on other people, I have destroyed their character, their personality, and their identity.”

Lord, I know many people would not like that, but I would be ok with that for myself.

“And you will never fall outside my will Jon Paul. You have my spirit in you, and he is the one giving you that desire. What I have promised you will not fail. And if you ask I will show you ways you are walking outside of my will.”

What is the will of God?

“Who is God?”

… Big question... Kind, good, generous, gracious, compassionate, perfect...

“Perfectly good. What you have described is my will.”

Do you cause pain to teach lessons?

“That is a bigger discussion than you want to have now. But to answer briefly, no. I will never cause pain to my children. They do fall into pain when they turn to themselves and steer into a pit. But I have a redemption plan for each one. No, pain is not my gain. And I will say that very strongly.”

But it seems there are many scriptures that say you do use pain?

“We will have this discussion soon. You can rejoice in pain because my grace is sufficient and you can glory in your troubles because I will reward you. You can learn from your mistakes, but I forgive you. So pain has some value. Pain is how the world learns. But I train my children through grace. “The grace of God has appeared to all men, it teaches us to say no to ungodliness and to live upright and holy lives in this present age. The world learns through mistakes, but you learn from My Wisdom. To make pain equal with God is folly. I do not take pleasure in the suffering of my children. Jon Paul, do not treat this subject lightly to please certain people.”

Lord, how can... without pain...

“Are you startled by what I said? A kingdom divided against itself can not stand. If I do the work of the adversary, who's kingdom am I supporting? It is the kindness of God that leads you to repentance. If you have made pain your God, be careful who you are serving.”

So, you don't play with pain?

“I took your pain at the cross Jon Paul so you would not have to endure it from me. There is pain in this world, but I have overcome the world, and my shadow is over you protecting you from harm. Do not be surprised that I do not like pain, even if you are taking the world's perspective. I will oppose any who challenge me on this issue.”

Your compassionate...

“I am life giving. Light has no fellowship with darkness. I love you Jon Paul. Love does no harm to its neighbor.”

item.title: Conversations with God - Part 3 Hearing God's voice
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
Again, if you haven't read Conversations with God 1 or 2 I would highly recommend reading them first. Somethings written here are in context and need to be understood like that. Before I begin I want to share one quote from the Lord about hearing his voice. "The key to hearing my voice all the time Jon Paul, is to get rid of everything that says you can't."

Hearing God's Voice

Hey God! I'm back and ready for more.

“Glad to hear it. What shall we talk about today?”

Well, we've talked about grace, your will, and whether or not you cause pain. What would the world ask you if they could?

“How do you hear God's voice?”

That's a great one. How do we hear your voice? How am I hearing your voice now?

“The Holy Spirit will speak to you in any way possible. You have trained yourself to recognize my voice by the words I speak. That is not the only way people can hear my voice, but it the the primary one for you. My voice is given freely to all who desire or ask, I do not withhold my words from the one who is listening. Man has limited the reasons why I may speak. They feel their voice is better than God's. They encourage you to ignore my words and to listen to conventional human wisdom. The man without the Spirit does not accept the things that come from the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness to him. This is why it seems hard to hear my voice. Because it is not popular. For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and become united to his wife, and the two will be one flesh. You are united with me in spirit, but you must come out of the doctrines and wisdom of the world if you are to pursue my theology. Your “parents” represent the basic principles of the world. The spirit does not operate by the basic principles of the world, in him is heavenly wisdom. If you are to believe the things I teach and say, you must have your mind renewed and open to my words. The spiritual man makes judgments about all things, but he himself is not subject to any man's judgment. What this passage is saying is that to operate in heavenly wisdom you must have discernment, to judge what is of God and what is of man. And let no man tell you otherwise.“

So are you saying you are always speaking we just must learn to pay attention and accept your truth?

“I am always speaking yes. I never withhold my words from the one who seeks. But my words will not profit a man unless it is mixed with faith. That man must accept the things that come from God and loose his taste for the wisdom of this world. They are contrary on many levels.”

How do you define, 'the one who seeks'?

“If while you are listening to this, you have a desire burning in you to hear God's voice, that is the seeking of the heart. If you are just curious you are still seeking, but reluctantly. Many people do not hear my voice often because they have decided in their hearts that I will not speak to them and they close their pursuit of my voice. They stop seeking, because they don't believe they will be rewarded.”

So you are promising that those who seek will hear your voice?

“Yes. I speak to all freely and without reproach.”

That's a passage from James about wisdom.

“Heavenly wisdom.”

So basically man gives up?

“Looses his hope and eventually his pursuit. You almost gave up a couple times. But I taught you to hold on and believe that I have no reason not to talk with you. Your reward, you hear me everyday without hinderance.”

Please explain that idea... that you have no reason not to talk with us.

“I am not reluctant to speak. Some have taught that a wise man holds his tongue, so they suspect I am holding my tongue. That my wisdom is reserved for the elite citizens of heaven, who pray and fast and confess. They are no more qualified than you or anyone I speak to. Look at the people in the Bible I spoke to. Did they fast? Did they seek? Did they pray? Some people teach that I have reasons for withholding my voice from you. They believe they are rewarded for their good works or deserving deeds. But I am kind to the ungrateful and the evil. Tell me a reason I would not talk to you?”

Because we have not listened and obeyed the last thing you said.

“If a child does not obey his father, does the father stop speaking to the child? Would he not insist? The spirit reminds you of the things God has said.”

Some say you have to have a gift to hear your voice?

“Only the gift of being loved. No, there is no gift described in the Bible that one must have to hear God's voice.” (Except the spirit of God)

What about the gifts of the spirit? Couldn't they be interpreted as hearing God's voice?

“The scripture says, if any of you lacks wisdom he should ask God, who gives freely to all without finding fault and it will be given to him. No those other verses could not be interpreted as God only giving his voice to certain classes.”

So, let's say a man is just pursuing hearing your voice. What tips would you give him?

“I will speak to him.”

Wow. Is there anything else he needs to know?

“If he is pursuing my voice, then he already believes I will speak to him. Beyond that, he only has to come and continue coming. Don't let him be discouraged. I have never refused to talk to anyone nor will I do so. This topic is throughly covered.”

One last question?

“Ok. You are asking for wisdom.”

What does God's voice sound like?

“I sound like myself. Whatever is pure, whatever is noble, whatever is good and perfect, whatever brings peace and happiness. Whatever seems right and pleasant. Whatever is true and trustworthy, that is the sound of my voice. I will never speak deceit, I will never speak harshly to my children. I do not criticize, I do no harm. I am not prideful nor arrogant. I do not speak evil. But only what is good and profitable for a man to hear so that his heart may be encouraged. This is the strengthening of the Lord. The other voice is the accuser who brings accusations against my children, he makes himself attractive as an angel of light. His words are not based on truth. He is the upholder of the law.”

Wait? The enemy an upholder of the law? Isn't that backwards?

“He uses the law to condemn those who have faith in Christ.”

Why does he do that?

“He wants to make you a slave to your works so you forget the free gift of righteousness and follow your own righteousness. Man is not justified by his works, but by my gift. He uses the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.”

I think we've just started our next discussion.

item.title: Conversations with God - The Knowledge of Good and Evil
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
Conversations with God

I'm going to attempt to share something personal and possibly offensive, but on the flip side could be very encouraging and life-giving. I believe God speaks to us today, and I have decided to share one of my conversations with him to the public. This puts me in a very humble place. Who am I to say what God is saying? But I ask you to weight and test the things I announce as coming from God. Basically I sit down at my computer, ask God a question, and type almost whatever I hear. This means some of the thoughts may be my own. I try to use discernment and much of the time I do hear God's voice. On occasion however, I can mishear something. So use discernment and give me grace to have heard incorrectly. Otherwise, be encouraged! O! And be gentle in the comments please, I am in a humble position.

The Knowledge of Good and Evil

[caption id="attachment_150" align="alignright" width="225" class=" "] Lower Falls at Yellow Stone National Forest[/caption] Lord, you've spoken a lot to me about this subject, but how would you speak to someone who's never heard this message? “I would tell them that the knowledge of good and evil is not good for man to eat. They would ask, what is the knowledge of good and evil. And I would tell them this. It is the awareness of your sin, the message of shame. It is the law in all its convicting power.” What does that look like practically? How do I know if I'm listening to the knowledge of good and evil or you? “The spirit will guide you into all truth. But the message of the law and prophets is according to that knowledge. The message of the wrath of God poured out on sinners is that message. The message of shame is that message. The message of pain and suffering is that message. If it subtracts from the righteousness of Christ, then it is the message of shame. You will know it by its fruit. It takes my children's confidence and turns their hearts to lead. They cannot serve me under that knowledge. They are doing themselves ill. The message of shame is the message of death and condemnation.”
"If it subtracts from the righteousness of Christ, then it is the message of shame."
God, how do we live without that knowledge? “Very simply, in the love and provision of your Father, no longer in the awareness of your sin.” Then how do you correct your children without the awareness of sin? “Love keeps no record of wrongs. A sinful behavior may be changed, but it is not credited to your account. If you want to live perfect, then be merciful as your heavenly father is merciful."
"If you want to live perfect, then be merciful as your heavenly father is merciful."
Help me to see the difference between correction and the knowledge of good and evil. “Correction must be mixed with the grace of God. If you try to live righteously under the law, your efforts will fail. The law does not make anyone righteous but holds everyone accountable to God.”
"Correction must be mixed with the grace of God."
What happens when a believer is trying to become more righteous? “I suppose you're meaning in his actions? Holy Living? In grace he will succeed every time. But apart from Me he can do nothing.” So then how do we approach becoming better people? “Your heart must be established in the grace of God. Do not think I was joking when I said apart from Me you can do nothing. Man's efforts to redeem himself always backfire. Maturity can not come from the will and effort of man. If they could be achieved, Christ died for nothing.” You say man's efforts cannot succeed? Are you suggesting we should give up on our efforts to live holy? “Who makes you holy?” You do. “If you are trusting in my efforts then you will lay aside your efforts. Your conscience feels comfortable and secure if you are taking effort to fix yourself, but my grace is established in rest, not in striving.”
"Your conscience feels comfortable and secure if you are taking effort to fix yourself, but my grace is established in rest, not in striving.”
So we should just rest and let you fix us? “Let my goodness lead you to repentance. When you are sick where do you go?” To the hospital! “Sin is like a sickness, and only my love can cure it. Your conscience and all its guilt cannot cure that sickness. No matter how hard you will, you cannot will away that sickness. Sickness is taken away with the proper care and treatment. Unless you rest, your body will not recover.” So we really should rest... and look to you and your love for us. “It is not until you receive the gift of no condemnation that you will be able to walk free of your sin. I am not advocating sin. This is not a license to practice immorality, it is a license to be loved unconditionally. And my love will take all roots of sin out of your life.”
“It is not until you receive the gift of no condemnation that you will be able to walk free of your sin. This is not a license to practice immorality, it is a license to be loved unconditionally."
So what shall I do when I find a sinful habit in my life? “Where do sinful habits come from?” I have no idea... “Identity theft.” Huh? “You have been made forever righteousness by the work of my son, when you know that, it stops the power of sin in your life.” So your saying those patterns emerge from me not believing that you made me righteousness. “As long as you think you've earned your righteousness, you will also think you can loose it. So when you find patterns of sin in your life, instead of falling into terror and worrying about the next time you will commit the sin, let your mind be renewed in the grace of God, letting him convict you of righteousness and bring out that fruit in your life.”
“As long as you think you've earned your righteousness, you will also think you can loose it."
So I should be convicted of righteousness while I'm sinning? That seems backwards! “Where does sin come from?” Does it really come from identity theft? Couldn't it come from me just not trying hard enough or me living in rebellion? “Trying is not succeeding. And rebellion is not covered in this lesson. Yes Jon Paul, sin really does come from identity theft. As long as you let the enemy tell you who you are, you behave in that same manner.” So our living comes out of our identity? “The righteous shall live by faith.” So we fail because we've forgotten that we are righteous. “Remember Lion King? Simba was falsely accused and believed the lie. That stole his identity from him and he lived as an outsider though he was really the king. In the same way, when one of my children gives into the liar and forgets his place in my kingdom, righteousness becomes unworthy of him (in his mind). When his mind is renewed to the truth or his kingship or position in my kingdom, he takes back the ground he lost! Focusing on the sin is not the root of the problem, and it only makes things worse. When identify is restored, his actions will follow.” Why are actions tied to identity? “Identity is the description of how you function. The knowledge of sin brings a false identity to believers.” Do you think its good to be convicted of sin? “When you convict a person of sin, you stop the growth of righteousness in their life. It produces the exact opposite fruit of what was intended. That is the nature of the law. It brings wrath, not salvation. When you convict a believer of sin, you are destroying their confidence and faith in God, that he justifies the ungodly. You must realize that God will by no means remember or recall their sins." Then how do we train others to behave appropriately? “In identity, in faith, in grace. In patience and hope. Don't give up on your redeemer.” The scripture confirms that. It says, 'If, while we seek to be justified in Christ, it becomes evident that we ourselves are sinners, does that mean that Christ promotes sin? Absolutely not! ...I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ died for nothing!' Its saying that if we find sin in our lives, we should not revert back to the law to fix it, but hold faithfully to grace! “That's very good! Who taught you that?” Your spirit did! “I give you the credit for accepting it. I am very proud of you! Take that and apply it to areas of weakness in your life. When you sin, do you revert back to judgement and condemnation to fix those things, or do you still consider yourself righteous and forgiven because of what Christ has done?” I believe that's true, but it seems arrogant. Who am I to believe I am righteous after I sin? “Who are you not to? Your sin does not make you righteous, my work does. When you believe you are righteous you are honoring me, when you revert to the law you are honoring yourself and worshiping your sin. If you want sin to loose dominion over you, you must revert to grace and not the law for edification. The strength of sin is the law. It is not a trick verse. Sin becomes powerful in your life when you are under condemnation. Reject it, standing firm in the grace of God, and do not let a man nor anything created tell you otherwise. It is my grace that justifies not your efforts.”
"If you want sin to loose dominion over you, you must revert to grace and not the law for edification. Sin becomes powerful in your life when you are under condemnation."
My conscience doesn't always agree with that. “Your conscience is part of your mind and can be renewed. I feel like this topic is appropriately addressed.” “Your conscience is part of your mind and can be renewed." Me too. Thanks God! You're awesome! I love you so much! “My grace to you! Be happy loved one! You are highly favored in the Beloved.” Why do you have all these conversations with me? “The same reason why you have them with Me.”

item.title: Free from Generational Curse
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
Here is another popular question or subject in the church. Is the Believer still under generational curse? There are many programs devoted to removing generation curse and inner healing. And some produce genuine testimonies. I think that God can use this ministry according to the faith of those in, however, I don't think it is God's best for us. I am throughly convinced that the believer is no longer under generational curse. Here is a blog on the subject. The New Creation CANNOT be under Generational Curse.  I would highly recommend reading this article, it carefully explains it. However, I would add that we are not only free from generational curse, but we are free completely from the curse of the law, our sins, or any malicious things the enemy or someone might speak over us.
"Like a flitting sparrow or a fluttering swallow, an undeserved curse goes nowhere" (Proverbs 26:2).
"Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us, for it is written: 'Cursed is everyone who is hung on a tree.' He redeemed us in order that the blessing given to Abraham might come to the Gentiles through Christ Jesus, so that by faith we might receive the promise of the Spirit" (Galatians 3:13).
According to the New Testament, now that we are righteous by faith, no curse is deserved, even when we sin. I hear a lot of talks about how this sin or that sin opened up the door for the enemy to work in their life and there are a lot of ministries that work on shutting doors your sin might have opened. Revelation 3:7 says,
"What he opens no one can shut, and what he shuts no one can open."
Are you a "one?" If God, through his son has shut the door to curses on your life and has opened a door to blessings, you, being a "one" cannot open it again, or shut the door to blessings.
"the one who was born of God keeps him safe, and the evil one cannot harm him" (1 John 5:18).
I'm not against deliverance ministries. There are some people who see some healing in them. I however left more discouraged and broken and paranoid than I came in with. I bet God works with us where we are at, in their level of faith. But I do not believe it is the perfect form. Sometimes, we make it seem like the enemy is more powerful in the believers life than God is. People switch their focus off of God and onto fighting the enemy, who is already defeated! They attribute the bad things that happen in their life to some kind of curse or open door. But, if you truely want to resist the enemy, that is not how you do it. The scripture says,
"Resist him, standing firm in the faith, because you know that the family of believers throughout the world is undergoing the same kind of sufferings" (1 Peter 5:9).
To resist the enemy, you don't fight him, you stand firm in your faith. You keep your eyes on God and He will fight your battles for you. He has already defeated the power of the enemy on your life. If you continue to fight the enemy you are still believing he has power! Don't be quoting scriptures against the enemy that he has no power while the very motive for you doing so is believing he has power! Eventually you'll talk yourself out of it! Of course, if it helps your confidence and faith remember those scriptures. But realize, that the enemy cannot touch your life. I used to be worried and fearful of demons or any teaching related to it. I was so paranoid, I couldn't function properly in public and my parents eventually talked to me about it. It is so important that you understand that the enemy doesn't have power or permission to work in the believer's life. Bad things may happen, but don't always attribute that to the enemy or a curse. I suppose you can think of it that way if you want, no evil thing comes from God. But I once had a pastor say, "You know, when my water heater goes out. I don't start rebuking the enemy and casting him out, I call the plumber." The primary way the enemy tries to discourage the believer is through inspiring others who are under his control to persecute you for your beliefs. That's why the apostles faced such persecution and he tells them to hold fast, because others are enduring the same kinds of persecutions. The enemy's primary goal is not to cause you to sin. It only takes one to make you guilty of all, but also all your sins are forgiven! He achieves near nothing from that. His primary role is to convince you that you are not forgiven, not under God's favor and grace, and have somehow lost your salvation or righteousness. He wants you to put your eyes on yourself. He uses the law to bring condemnation on you. That is why you must stand firm in your faith. Not faith that you've done enough good. Faith that you've been forgiven enough! Faith says, "God has made me righteous forever by his son, and there is no condemnation for my sins."
"And no wonder, for even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light. So it is no surprise if his servants, also, disguise themselves as servants of righteousness" (2 Corinthians 11:14-15). "See to it that no one takes you captive through hollow and deceptive philosophy, which depends on human tradition and the basic principles of this world rather than on Christ. When you were dead in your sins and in the uncircumcision of your sinful nature, God made you alive with Christ. He forgave us all our sins, having canceled the written code, with its regulations, that was against us and that stood opposed to us; he took it away, nailing it to the cross. And having disarmed the powers and authorities, he made a public spectacle of them, triumphing over them by the cross" (Colossians 2 scattered).
God took away the weapon of the enemy, which is the "written code, with its regulations." The enemy is a minister of righteousness not of sin. But he uses righteousness to condemn you not to impart it too you. Of course, by tangling the believer up under the law, the result is more sin. But his goal is to make you feel condemned through how others falsely say all kinds of evil against you and persecute you. Imagine these disciples, teaching the grace of God and having Jews come up and rebuke and persecute them for teaching against the law of Moses. The Jews were coming to minister "righteousness" and condemn the disciples' faith. That is why they must hold firm to their faith, even when it causes that trouble. Peter is saying to take comfort in the fact that others are enduing the same kinds of trials. So anyways, that is my rant on curses. I hope you were encouraged. My goal is that you become settled in your mind that no curse that God has not given shall overtake you. And under Christ, God will not ever curse you either. Be confident and expect his favor and blessings. For with the same token that he said Christ took your curse, he also said so that the blessings of Abraham might be guaranteed. That is your inheritance, not your struggle. Thanks for reading.

"who claims to specialize in possessions, demonic presence, legal rights of demons, personal responsibility in removing curses, or falling under hexes from occult objects, ." I did used to believe these things and they used to terrify me. I also once thought I had a demon. I went to a deliverance center to get it cast out and screamed and thought I saw a dragon. In fact, I was better off before I listened to these kind of teachings. It's remarkable how real some of these stories seem, but I don't believe them. But, these spiritual warfare ideas are not biblical. There is no instance of a christian in the bible having a demon. Those two people in Acts who were trying to cast a demon out were not christians. The demon said, "Paul I know, but who are you?" I believe he knew Paul because Paul was God's child. These men saw the miracles Paul was doing and tried to repeat them using Jesus's name. But because they didn't believe in Jesus it didn't work for them. 

Demon's have no legal right in the believers life. Corinthians tells us he has disarmed the principalities and powers. No, we cannot open doors to them." What God has sealed with the death and resurrection of his son cannot be undone by an idle word. "A door the Lord shuts no man can open, and a door the Lord opens no man can shut." There is no curse, Christ redeemed us from the curse as Galatians tells us. You will never find any instances of items infecting people with curses in the new testament. Paul was even brave enough to eat foods that were sacrificed to idols if they did not bother other people's conscience.

These teachings are unbiblical, unhealthy, and dangerous. They destroy lives and do not produce the fruit of the kingdom. But, our church has stopped pursuing these things, probably because we've realized they are unbiblical.

And yes, I have talked to the Lord about it. I believe the Lord has told me that demons want nothing to do with Christians, they are afraid of them. They will flee wherever you go!

item.title: Conversations with God - How do I know when its God speaking?
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
As the Lord was opening up the door for me to hear his voice continually we had this conversation early on where I gave him my complaints and struggled with the question, 'how do I know if it's God speaking to me?' You know the best person to ask such a question to is God. I want to encourage you to ask God questions like this and to talk to Him yourself if you don't already. Hearing God's voice is not a gift given only to the elite, its given to all christians or any who would ask. There are a couple references to stories and things He told me prior to this conversation. That I can share later. But I'm skipping the first part of the conversation because of personal content, so you will be dropping in right in the middle. (Again, with all my other conversations with God, I often hear God's voice correctly but many times I mishear, so please use discernment as you read and give me grace to hear him incorrectly at times. I wouldn't dare post a blog like this if I didn't have that grace. Be encouraged and if you disagree with a point, please be gentle in your comments. I'm in a humble position.)

How Do I Know its God

I want it to be real. Not my imagination. “So do I.” How do we go from here then? If my imagination gets in the way of hearing your voice sometimes, and I don't have tangible proof, how am I to know your voice from mine? “When a father speaks to his son, do you think the son will know his father's voice?” Yes. But a son hears his father physically. How do you distinguish a spiritual voice? “Do you require training?” That's what I'm asking. “A spiritual voice is no different from a physical voice. But I will enter your frustration. WHERE IS EVIDENCE THAT I AM SPEAKING?” That's it. I'd like to hear your take on it. “The evidence is in my character.” What is your character? “Do you really want to know?” Yes. “Look at that book by Joseph Prince.” What about... “Who is asking you these questions?” The world. I don't want to hear your voice wrong. Can I hear your voice without hearing it wrong? “There is grace for hearing my voice wrong. Remember the story of the 15 pencils?” How could I forget! “It impressed you?!” Yes. I love it when you do that! But how do I go from hearing you as often as I do to staying in a place of hearing your thoughts? “By grace.” Please explain? “Seek and you will find, knock and the door will open.” I don't want to reject what you say, but I've felt a lot of unsuccessful attempt at that. What do I do when it seems dry and empty? “You are not rejecting me, you want to understand. Don't ask and expect not to receive.”
"Don't ask and expect not to receive."
Are you saying not to be discouraged if it doesn't happen right away? “I'm sorry. I do hear your prayer right away. And I do answer it right away. When did this happen?” When I was in Nashville with my dad in his temporary house. I tried hard to hear your voice, and asked, and yearned and could not hear beyond my own thoughts. “I saw. You were beating on the door.” Does that mean I didn't expect you to answer? “It means your desire was strong. Don't be discouraged. I do answer when you knock.” I believe that. Does it have to take a long time? “I usually don't tarry.” Then where does the wait come from? I know I'm asking a big philosophical question. I don't need the answer for the world. Just one that will comfort me. “I am preparing a bigger answer than you expected.” I see that we don't always experience that on earth. I guess its one of those ignorance things. I guess I just need my experiences to adjust. “Keep talking like that and your experiences will change a lot. You didn't know that I heard you.” Do I have to do anything mentally to hear your voice when I'm really wanting to hear it? Do you just speak only when you want to? “You don't have to do anything. My spirit is in you. Become aware that I don't take your prayers for granted. I believe the church calls it a posture of receiving. A place of mental realization, contemplation, dependency, without thought or concern. You want to know if its easier to hear my voice in this posture?” Yes. “You only have to know that I speak.” What about tuning into the spirit? How do you tune into the spirit? Why does it seem harder at some times more than others. “Learning to live through the spirit is learning to cease living by the flesh. Sometimes you have to put fleshly things aside to move unhindered. This means listening with a heart prepared to accept and change.” What does the flesh look like practically? How do you see it? “When it comes to hearing my voice? Being able to believe that God could be speaking even when you can't hear him with your ears. Hearing God's voice is a practice of grace. But most importantly of discernment. Give time for discernment. Do not rush to conclusions.” Why can't hearing you voice be like hearing anybody else's? “Because anybody else's voice is not worth hearing as much.” Yea. “There's no pressure for you to get it right.” So how do I know its you?! I'm so eager to know this! I want to experience the answer. How do I know its you? “By faith.” (That statement brought me to tears.) How do you measure faith? How can it be proved or disproved? How does one believe what doesn't have solid evidence? “By closing your eyes.” You mean flesh's eyes? “Faith is the evidence of things unseen. Not the evidence of things seen. I can't answer your question until you answer one of mine.” What is your question? “Do you think I am quiet?” No. “Then I will answer your question. We live by faith and not by sight.”

item.title: The 15 Pencils
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded: This was a personal encounter I had with God one day. The same encounter I reference in my other blog entry, "Conversations with God - How Do I Know if I'm hearing God's Voice." It had been quite some time since I had heard God so clearly as that day. So I took the opportunity to test whether I was really hearing God or not. I had been packing for my trip to college and a bag of pencils had spilt on the ground. It was the first thing that grabbed my attention. I said, "God, if this is you speaking to me, can you tell me how many pencils are on the ground?" I then tried intently to listen and I heard, "15, 12, 18, 7..." I knew it was my imagination but I was frustrated that I couldn't tell which one was God. Then God spoke clearly to me and said, "How many do you think there are?" I said, "15." God said, "Count them and I'll make up the difference." I didn't understand what he meant, but I counted the pencils and there were 10. Immediately I realized that the difference was 5 and I was reminded of a sermon by Joseph Prince I had listened to 2 days prior on how the number 5 in the Bible represents the letter for "grace." From that, I realized what the Lord was saying. I heard his voice wrong, but his grace made up the difference! I was amazed and said, "God! You did know how many pencils were on the ground!" He said, "I knew, but you didn't need to know. What you needed to know is that my grace will cover you when you mishear my voice." So don't be afraid to hear God's voice. Most of the time you will hear Him correctly, but sometimes every now and then we have heard his voice incorrectly. Don't let that discourage you however, because God's grace makes up the difference!
