item.title: 1 Corinthians 3
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
(For those of you who got my email on this passage earlier, I deleted the old post and started from scratch. You are welcome to read my revised version, but the basic content is the same.) Let's look at a difficult passage of scripture.
1 Corinthians 3:10-15 “According to the grace of God which was given unto me, as a wise master builder I laid a foundation; and another builds thereon. But let each man take heed how he builds thereon. For other foundation can no man lay than that which is laid, which is Jesus Christ. But if any man builds on the foundation gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, stubble; each man’s work shall be made manifest: for the day shall declare it, because it is revealed in fire; and the fire itself shall prove each man’s work of what sort it is. If any man’s work shall abide which he built thereon, he shall receive a reward. If any man’s work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as through fire.”
Wayne Jackson and Edward Hendrie posted incredible articles on this passage that I wanted to forward for those of you who've wondered about it. Wayne Jackson - https://www.christiancourier.com/articles/875-does-1-cor-3-15-support-the-doctrine-of-eternal-security https://www.christiancourier.com/articles/1066-1-corinthians-3-15-saved-through-fire Edward Hendrie- http://www.antichristconspiracy.com/PDFDocs/2Corinthians5.pdf I have some additional confirmation from my own studies, but I am mostly recapping what they said. For the context of this passage we need to understand that Paul is dealing with heresies coming into the church from other teachers.
1 Corinthians 15 "12 But if it is preached that Christ has been raised from the dead, how can some of you say that there is no resurrection of the dead? 13 If there is no resurrection of the dead, then not even Christ has been raised. 14 And if Christ has not been raised, our preaching is useless and so is your faith." 1 Corinthians 4 "19 But I will come to you very soon, if the Lord is willing, and then I will find out not only how these arrogant people are talking, but what power they have. 20 For the kingdom of God is not a matter of talk but of power."
These teachers were spreading heresies that had so far departed from the gospel they had lost their power to produce genuine faith. So let's tie this in with our passage of study. We must ask what is each man's work, what is the reward, what is the fire, and what are the building blocks.

What, or rather who, are the building blocks?

Let's look at the passaged before and after our main passage of study. Just before the passage he says,
1 Corinthians 3 "5 What, after all, is Apollos? And what is Paul? Only servants, through whom you came to believe—as the Lord has assigned to each his task. 6 I planted the seed, Apollos watered it, but God has been making it grow. 7 So neither the one who plants nor the one who waters is anything, but only God, who makes things grow. 8 The one who plants and the one who waters have one purpose, and they will each be rewarded according to their own labor. 9 For we are co-workers in God’s service; you are God’s field, God’s building."
I think this begins to answer what he's talking about. Paul's work is preaching the gospel, in building up the church, and he will have a reward from it. The building blocks are the people who are impacted from his ministry ("[you are] God's building") and the reward is those he won over to Christ because of his preaching.
1 Corinthians 9 "Are you not the result of my work in the Lord? 2 Even though I may not be an apostle to others, surely I am to you!" 1 Thessalonians 2:19 "After all, what gives us hope and joy, and what will be our proud reward and crown as we stand before our Lord Jesus when he returns? It is you!" 1 Corinthians "16 For when I preach the gospel, I cannot boast, since I am compelled to preach. Woe to me if I do not preach the gospel! 17 If I preach voluntarily, I have a reward; if not voluntarily, I am simply discharging the trust committed to me. 18 What then is my reward? Just this: that in preaching the gospel I may offer it free of charge, and so not make full use of my rights as a preacher of the gospel." 1 Corinthians 10 "32 Do not cause anyone to stumble, whether Jews, Greeks or the church of God— 33 even as I try to please everyone in every way. For I am not seeking my own good but the good of many, so that they may be saved."
These people are a church that is growing, a temple that is being preserved, a building that is being constructed with good material, a field that is being watered.
1 Corinthians 3 "16 Don’t you know that you yourselves are God’s temple and that God’s Spirit dwells in your midst? 17 If anyone destroys God’s temple, God will destroy that person; for God’s temple is sacred, and you together are that temple. 18 Do not deceive yourselves. If any of you think you are wise by the standards of this age, you should become “fools” so that you may become wise."
The 'you' is talking corporately not so much individually. If someone dismantles God's church (through spreading false doctrines that keep people from coming to the faith), God will overthrow him. So those illegitimate teachers who think they are wise by the standards of this age, must humble themselves so they do not preach against the finished work of Christ and risk building with low quality materials. When Paul talks about each man's work, its easy to get the idea he is talking about how righteous you have behaved. That is how many sins you have avoided and how many good deeds you did. But when he talks about the quality of each man's work, being gold, silver, straw, or wood, I believe the context shows us that he is referring to the quality of faith teacher's followers receive from their ministry. He is encouraging them to be careful how they teach so that only enduring faith may result, not vain, temporal faith (as in the idea that there is no resurrection or that Christ has not raised from the dead). If our building puts dependance back onto man's effort and works and leaves Christ behind, then we are building with low quality materials and the fires will reveal the fault in that preaching. Now the fires I suppose can refer to either the day of judgment or in the sense of the fire of persecution in this life. But either way, quality preaching, that is preaching that has its foundation in Christ, has the power to produce genuine enduring faith, and the fire will prove their faith and preaching was legitimate. Thus the reward of our work is the satisfaction and honor of having so many people brought to the Lord because of our ministry. When we go to heaven there will be hundreds of people following us there because of our preaching. Its going to fill our hearts with joy. And they will be extremely grateful toward us for the rest of eternity.  It will be a joyous celebration and we will get to live with them forever. I believe this is the reward he is talking about. Thus, when our ministry teaches belief systems that drift off of the foundation of Christ and into dead works or if our own beliefs reflect that, in the final day you will find that those teachings and beliefs we held became a loss to us. That is, they never helped people genuinely believe in Christ and our own beliefs did not glorify him. You yourself are saved, but only as one being saved in the midst of a worthless ministry and labor. God is not holding you responsible for people's faith and he does not require us to all have perfect belief systems, but there is a warning that preaching must be solid and worthy of Christ.
"If any man’s work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as through fire.”
There are some who would preach that there are certain special works you need to do in order to be saved or have a good relationship with God. Now, we must forgive these people, for they preach from their own misunderstanding of the bible, but we need to not go adrift from their preaching. Remember my article on Hebrews 6? Dead works are a good example of a faulty belief system. They keep us in the cycle of performing useless rituals that insult Christ and add nothing of value to our lives. When we drift off of the foundation of Christ, it is tempting to fall into these rituals as a means to stay right with God. However, the final day will reveal the error of those ways as we will realize the uselessness of all that insulting labor. In a sense, we will suffer the loss of our pride and realize all the effort we put into offering those rituals was a waste. He warns them not to associate with those teachers.
1 Corinthians 15 "33 Do not be misled: “Bad company corrupts good character.”[e] 34 Come back to your senses as you ought, and stop sinning; for there are some who are ignorant of God—I say this to your shame." 1 Corinthians 15 "58 Therefore, my dear brothers and sisters, stand firm. Let nothing move you. Always give yourselves fully to the work of the Lord, because you know that your labor in the Lord is not in vain."

Recap

So to recap,
1 Corinthians 3:10-15 “According to the grace of God which was given unto me, as a wise master builder I laid a foundation; and another builds thereon. But let each man take heed how he builds thereon. For other foundation can no man lay than that which is laid, which is Jesus Christ. But if any man builds on the foundation gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, stubble; each man’s work shall be made manifest: for the day shall declare it, because it is revealed in fire; and the fire itself shall prove each man’s work of what sort it is. If any man’s work shall abide which he built thereon, he shall receive a reward. If any man’s work shall be burned, he shall suffer loss: but he himself shall be saved; yet so as through fire”
It is a warning to teachers, that they should be careful how they preach. For if their ministry departs too far from the true gospel, their work will have been in vain. This is not to say that minor differences in understanding the gospel will keep you from being saved. There are disputable areas in the Bible. But rather that, when the basic message of Jesus being Lord, how he died for us and rose again for our sins, and how he is the son of God, gets taken out of place, the gospel looses its power.

item.title: Conversations with God - Eternal Security
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
Here is a conversation I had with the Lord about eternal security which correlates with my other article Eternal Security. As always, I don't pretend to hear God perfectly so if you come across something that doesn't seem like God, ignore it and give me grace for such mistakes. I try to hear him as accurately as possible, but from time to time I can hear something wrong.

Conversation with God

God, I would really like to study and know how secure we are eternally. I think its pretty clear that we cannot mess up our calling by works. But could a person cease believing properly to an extent that he forfeits his calling?

“I know what you are asking. Once saved, always saved, or is there a back door? I can answer this question, but if you want me to be thorough it will take some time. We can start with what it means to be saved.”

Alright. I'm listening.

“When I call somebody, especially through the preaching of the word, my spirit works in them a lasting faith that believes in the message they heard. When I find that faith in operation, usually by means of the person saying, “Jesus is Lord,” I justify that person as in correct covenant with Me. Such a declaration cannot be reversed. It is like a court case. A penalty can only be tried and punished once.”

But Lord, you require faith to be saved? Sorry. I'll let you speak.

“When you are called, that is only the beginning. I mark you with a seal that guarantees you will receive an inheritance in the Lord. And this inheritance does not spoil. Can you loose it? No one has. You see, if you are saved based on the whims of your mind, then I must show special treatment to those who die just after giving their lives to the Lord. Such a timing guarantees they will be saved. However, if a man has been a christian for 60 years and in his final days he turns away, he would not be shown the mercy that man who received Jesus just before he died received. But Jon Paul, this leaves an important question. How do you know if you are saved?”

Lord? How?

“Works are an evidence of faith, but the do not guarantee it. Rather it is faith that guarantee's works. To answer this question, if a man denies that Jesus is Lord and that he died and rose for your sins, that man does not have the spirit in him. Such a man has never come to me. If on the other hand he believes that Jesus is the son of God and was crucified and raised from the dead for your sins, such a man has the holy spirit. Nothing can change his standing with me. The holy spirit is a deposit guaranteeing what is to come.”

What if for a time they believe you are Lord and then later decide that you are not?

“This is the issue of the Holy Spirit leaving you. The Holy Spirit will never leave you, he will be with you forever and ever. Such a man will grieve the spirit but the spirit will turn his heart and mind back to the Lord. To answer the question, that person shall be corrected, but they will not fall. The holy spirit does not give up on anybody.”

So God, what is 1 Colossians 1:23 saying? I just read it.

“Do you believe I can give you a straight answer?”

Yes Lord. But I will ask for a scripture. God why is it so hard to reach a conclusion on the eternal security issue. I know I can talk to you about anything.

“I am glad you are studying. Your confidence is low right now which is why you are having trouble hearing my voice. You don't know how to recognize the voice of your father. Answer me this question, when you read the scripture, what impression do you get?”

Well, I mostly get that our salvation is completely firm. But there are a few scriptures that say we can fall away.

“I am going to take you through verse by verse till you understand what scripture is saying. But before we start I want to ask you something.”

What's that?

“Do you trust me?”

Yes Lord.

“Turn to 1 Peter 1:5”

Alright. I have read it.

“What do you think it is saying?”

Well I'm not sure. I seems he's saying that God is keeping you safe from physical harm till the resurrection?

“First of all, I'm glad you are studying this topic and the Bible. It will be a great benefit to learn where you stand on this matter. Yes, that is a good interpretation. What do you think it means, through your faith?”

That's... well... I'm afraid it means as along as we have faith God protects us?

“It means God is protecting your faith.”

Ok, I'll take your word on that.

“This verse contains the entire mystery of eternal security.”

It does? So what if someone gives up on their faith?

“My power protects them even from that. Through faith is the means through which God protects them.”

So its saying our faith assures us of salvation and God protects us through keeping up our faith?

“A better word for it is preserve. Who through God are preserved for the salvation that is yet to be revealed.”

So what about that annoying phrase through faith? How would you translate this verse for me?

“who through your active faith are preserved therein by God's power so that you may receive the promised inheritance. It is saying God's power is what preserves your faith until the end.”

It's not the other way around? Our faith preserves God's power?

“The weight of the verse is put on God's power which results in a sustained faith unto salvation.”

So what if we did fall away?

“I can loose none that he has given me.”

So we are guarantee'd to endure?

“Yes, your faith is guaranteed to endure.”

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Jon Paul, I love it! I have been meditating on 1 Peter 1:5 for weeks. This really helped me understand it more. I too felt the Spirit drawing me to that verse for assurance and security of salvation but did not see the full picture. 

Hebrews 11 says without faith it is impossible to please God. Hebrews 12 says Jesus is the Author and Perfector of that faith. Holy Spirit will preserve us by His power by strengthening and confirming our faith till the end. Praise God!!!

Good question. Saying, "God told me so," is not the end of a debate. There have been many times and still will be many times where I and others think we have heard God say something that He really didn't say. Learning to follow the Spirit can be messy at times. It's a messiness I've grown to accept, but it does mean we have to test and weigh what people claim is from God. Even my own messages need to be tested. 1 John 4:1 "Dear friends, do not believe every spirit, but test the spirits to see whether they are from God, because many false prophets have gone out into the world." 1 Corinthians 14:29 "Two or three prophets should speak, and the others should weigh carefully what is said." People are not always intentionally trying to put words in God's mouth, but sometimes in all honesty we have misunderstood. I'm very slow to call someone a false prophet. We all have a responsibility to use God's words with respect and reverently, but unless they are intentionally putting words in God's mouth I do not call them a false prophet. Yes, I believe they are sincere Christians who have good works. And then other times they may have genuinely heard from God but they misunderstand his meaning and say something other than what he meant. I gauge what I hear in my spirit. "But the wisdom from above is first of all pure. It is also peace loving, gentle at all times, and willing to yield to others. It is full of mercy and good deeds. It shows no favoritism and is always sincere" (James 3:17). If it isn't merciful, not peaceful, not gentle, not pure and impartial, insincere, doesn't produce good fruit, then I usually don't accept it as God. But, when we can't tell if it's God or not, it's best to pray about the situation and let the Bible be the judge. I hope I won't mishear God's voice but I know one day I will, even in speaking publicly on this blog and I will need my readers' grace in order not to shy away from preaching about the Lord. So I would ask that you try to understand where he's coming from. I doubt he's intentionally trying to manipulate God's words, but he may or may not have misheard him. Use the Bible and the Holy Spirit within you to discern the matter.

Hey dude, could you do me a big favour ask the Lord about where anti-eternal-security preachers like Francis Chan who claim the Lord spoke against them with stuff like "there will be no cowards in heaven"? I can't help but feel uneasy about the fact that people preaching against eternal security claimed to have heard from God also. Are they lying? Who is providing their message? They seem sincere with many good works, miracles also.

Indeed brother Jon Paul. I agree that I shouldn't make an impression that the Bible is unreliable. Rather is to show that regardless of how reliable it is, it is notoriously hard to interpret given the lack of clarity against many things of central importance to the gospel

The Bible is not very well organized doctrinally. You've got to remember that Jesus spent his 4 books in NT without ever explicitly telling us his expectations regarding eternal salvation or lack of it after the cross. 

The second problem is again, ambiguous verses that could be interpreted both ways. Take Jesus' future prophecy about cutting down "trees that do not bear fruit". Law preachers say that arguments about rightly dividing the testaments don't apply here because Jesus is explicitly making a statement regarding the future. On one hand fruit never refers to grace in the Bible, on the other hand the grace preachers counter with "a good tree has no bad fruit-so don't bring works into it if you even have 1 fruit that is bad". On one hand we have Jesus' massive acts of forgiveness in the apostles' books that seem to prove eternal salvation, but the law preachers counter that every one of them-the adulterer-the tax collector, Peter who denied Christ, etc actually repented after their wrongs while many Christians can't really stop sinning. We have grace preachers countering that Jesus was a "friend of the sinners and drunkards" which probably means he never interfered with their ways in life and that his forgiveness is unconditional. Then we have law preachers citing the example of Simon the Sorcerer-he was referred to as "among the believers" yet he was not immune to Paul's curse of "rot with your money because you sought to buy the Holy Spirit with money. 

Another problem with radical grace's assumption of "rightly dividing the testaments" is this-unjustified ambiguity of the evidence of that assumption. Sure, Jesus ate with Zaccheaus, but it was not until Zaccheus promised to give back the money that Jesus said "today you are saved". Sure, Jesus exaggerated the law to the Pharisees, but if that is the purpose why did he exaggerate the law to disciples too? I.e. "if any of you do not forgive, my father will not forgive you", "deny my name and I will deny yours in front of the father". 

My problem with "trusting the Bible" on matters like these this-the ones that say it so confidently are the ones who get stumped on my questions all the time. I'm not demeaning the Bible-I'm saying that if anyone boasts that it is clear and easy to interpret, they ought to competently answer my questions. 

Sure, it is easy to have faith in the Bible if one barely read it and just ignore the scary verses, but then again that's not faith. That's just confidence ignited by foolishness and indifference or luck.

Also, Joseph Prince makes a lot of mistakes.

The journey in the desert-he says it was pure grace. But God got angry and allowed snakes to bite Israel until the bronze snake was carved. But was the snake given until repentance is given? Repentance did not come before the snake, it came after the snake.

He says that the law was given rather than Abraham's promise because man boasted to serve God. Yet it was God that first said "obey my laws and I will be your God" before Israel uttered "we will". Obviously it was God that brought it up first.

Prince says that grace was upon Abraham, but that was earned by obedience to sacrifice his son wasn't it?

What I mean is this-there are many parts of the Bible that we can trust. But on eternal security it is hard to generate trust because the arguments and counters and degree of ambiguity is too high. Once in a while someone like Joseph claims to write a "refute the opposition once and for all" book and the dummies who never read their Bible cheer on, but people like me are smart enough to realize that Joseph only dared to stick to Paul's writings instead of commenting on the harsh implications of James, Jude and Revelations, and even within Paul's writings he did not explain what "the fear of the Lord" is in Acts. Apparently he brushes it aside with "fear means reverence in Hebrew". But then where does the "work out your salvation with fear and trembling come from"? The word "trembling" he does not dare touch on. Timothy 5:8's comment on "worse than unbelievers" he does not dare touch on. 

And yes, Paul said in Romans "believe in the Lord Jesus Christ and you are saved". But he also said somewhere else "confess Jesus with your mouth and believe in your heart and you are saved". And then James started saying "the believers will be recognized by their fruit". Each one of these statements is incremental in its demands. Law preachers complain about us arbitrarily accepting the first without accepting the second (for those who do not dare to tell people they are Christians). And that's true. 

So then, what would I do in my case? I'd obviously go for someone with personal revelation since technical analysis clearly isn't working. But how do I know you are legit? 1) People don't just naturally imagine things like "search up 1st Peter 1:5" when they don't even know what that verse is. Many people who claim to talk to God only gets "yes or no" answers, but you got answers that require explanation and intellectual analysis. If you can shoot an arrow into space and make it travel forever, you may be 50/50 certain that it will reach a star. But to tell me which star it will land on is a feat to be reckoned with. 2) Many people who claim to talk to God anytime they want but cringe in fear when I ask them to reveal something about me. Why are they so scared if they claim to talk to God? 3) Many people who talk to God couldn't give an explanation at all about how they know it's an external source and not self-produced feelings or convos in the head-at least you talk about the details of the process 4) People who talk about God often don't have objective evidence to back stuff up-but stuff you talk about-eg "anger is just a different frequency of sadness"-how can you possibly dream up something that profound in your own mind? 5) Many people who claim to "speak to God" aren't stoked at all-I mean, how can you not be excited if you really can? You can ask them about all sorts of mysteries of the world-next week's lotto number, black eyed kids phenomenon...etc. Ok God probably withhold's the lotto numbers since he's not supposed to create massive physical interference on earth, but still, why aren't they excited if they can talk to God? And thinking about lotto randomly, why wouldn't God tell us lotto numbers if we asked? After all Job had 5000 sheep and Solomon's palace was supposedly worth $60 billion in our time. 

See, you meet all the right criteria. Although I'm a bit surprised you, your cousin and Conrad all got "science"-ish answers, I don't doubt you. You dared to attempt it with no fear-unlike the Christians I've met who would bring all sorts of excuses to stop me from testing them like that. After all it could even have been a demon trying to cram "science" in all three of your minds-you, your cousin and Conrad, to dissuade me from the true gospel.

One of the biggest false teachings that somehow crept into Baptist and evangelical theology is the idea that God gives internal personal revelations to today's Christians. 

"God moved me to..."
"God led me to..."
"God spoke to me in my heart..."

You won't find any such idea in the Bible. God speaks to Christians today through only ONE means:  his Word.

Want to know what God wills for you today and everyday?  Get out your Bible and start reading!

---brought to you by Martin Luther and the teachings of the (orthodox) Lutheran church
I can't find many stories in the Bible that don't include God directly speaking to or guiding someone. I don't understand why you don't see this as a Biblical concept.

Brother JonPaul, that is an excellent point. But I am not capable of testing the spirit, for I cannot work out the apparent contradictions behind the many Biblical verses. Also, I have not sensed the Holy Spirit for a long time. I cannot distinguish between "the right message" or just "me feeling happy". 

But can you do something similar to the "15 pencils test" to ask something for my sake? I am encouraged by your words but still a little scared inside. Can you ask God if I am saved forever? And also tell me what exam I have today? If you get it  right it will help me trust the Lord. If you can't get the answer I will not judge you. It is for my own sake that I ask this, not in my enjoyment of excessive testing and being a nuisance. I know God may not respond at demand, but you seem to be one who can talk with him for great lengths at a time. Can you please try it? I am shaken by the law preachers' testimonies. Please my brother. You said you can talk to the Lord even about mundane things like how computer pixels work. How much more then, is it worthy of a response when a person like me is cringing over their life and has not heard a single word from him in so many years? Have pity on me. If an apostle in the Bible believed in the Lord because he saw him behind the fig tree, can I not have a miraculous confirmation as well?

I understand and you have my compassion!!! 

It can be true that we can believe words came from God because they make us feel good when actually they haven't come from God. But more often than not we dismiss something God has told us that is good news because we think it's too good. The Gospel itself means, "Good News." 

I will talk to God about your situation! Remember, I don't always hear perfectly, there can be times where I hear one sentence right but the next incorrectly. This is because just as the Holy Spirit lives in me, so my own spirit lives within me and has its' own thoughts. I know God will respond, "If any of you lacks wisdom, you should ask God, who gives generously to all without finding fault, and it will be given to you" (James 1:5). 

I am not bothered by your request, I have found myself in the same situation before. I am worried however that I may hear incorrectly, but if you give me your grace I will take the risk of hearing Him wrong. I only ask if I do hear Him wrong at this point that you would not dismiss all hope of hearing God or believing your Salvation is secure. I firmly believe you are secure even if I hear incorrectly at times. 

I asked the Lord what exam you were taking tomorrow and I felt like I heard "Science" and then later "Chemistry." For confirmation I talked to my prophetic relative and my best friend Conrad who prophecies quite a bit. My relative at once heard "Physics." Conrad also heard "Physics" but second to that he heard "Chemistry or Science." 

Both Conrad and I heard that you were eternally secure. I was told that just as surely as a person cannot go back into the womb and be unborn, so you cannot reverse your salvation. Once you are justified by faith the case is sealed. It cannot be retried. God's reputation as upholding justice depends on it. 

Conrad also heard that you have been given a new nature that is irreversible, however he feels that your mind has not been renewed to the reality of your situation and is still thinking carnally. He wants you to know for sure you are eternally secure. 

Finally I felt like the Lord told me some other things.

Lord, what do you want to say to Simon?
“Tell Him I know his worries, that he wants to serve my will and that he does not have confidence that he can hear my voice. But I am in Him and I will give Him confidence to trust in my peace. Salvation is eternal because it relies on Christ and not what test you have today. I am glad he is seeking for help and wants to know what I have to say. Tell him I will be speaking to Him regularly. 

God wanted me to look up your name's meaning and it said, “He has heard.” I believe God wants you to know that He hears your distress and he is providing hope for you!

Hope this helps! I know I am taking a large risk, but I hope this is what you needed to hear.

It is absolutely true that the Bible is full of stories in which God speaks to individual believers.  How do we know that the "voice" that these believers say that they heard was really God?  How do we know that the voice they heard was not an evil spirit?  Or Satan?  Or just the person's own conscience talking?

We know that the voice was God's because the Bible, God's Word, tells us that it was!

Could God give personal revelations today to individual believers?  Sure!  He's God!  But the New Testament is clear that the WORD "is our guide", and a "lamp to our feet", not internal voices.

Unless God has included your private revelation in the Bible, there is no way to know for sure who's voice you are listening to in your heart.  God?  Maybe.  Satan?  Maybe.  YOU?  Probably.

"Thy Word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path."

Want to know God's will for you today and everyday?  Read your Bible!  And by the way, don't sit around and expect God to make all your decisions in life.  Just as in the Parable of the Talents, our Lord has given us each "talents" to use wisely.  He gives you the general principles to follow in his Word, but he wants YOU to make the wise decisions and make the wise "investments".

Waiting for God to make every decision for you in your life is a recipe for anxiety and depression.

Cling to the Word, not to internal voices, my Christian brother!

Brother, everyone knows to cling to the word, but how is it useful when interpreting the Word is extra hard? I'd rather trust internal voices when I've got myself stuck in a crack on Biblical interpretation.

Firstly there is the fact of overwhelming numerosity-endless circles of debates are written on the eternal security topic. Whose thesis are you going to trust when you see the Bible as contradictory and don't know where you've interpreted it wrongly? 

Many people who are so quick to say "rely on the word" doesn't realize that eternal security isn't something a 2 page internet rant or a 200 page pdf could solve convincingly. It would take maybe 2000 pages to clear the argument from both sides, which is complicated because each side has some classic verses the other avoids discussing

Even worse is the problem of ambiguity of context. Many verses can be interpreted in light of both  the side of demand and that of grace, so biblical scholars are relying on "what could be" to shove themselves out of the cracks. But simply proving what "could be" doesn't guarantee that that a verse positively supports a doctrine. 

Take the "don't mix new wine with old wineskin". Law preachers say that Jesus meant to say that once you have accepted Christ you need to put your old habits away, and grace preachers say that the old and new don't mix refers to the two covenants. Who is right? Hard to tell. 

Or Matthew 7:21. Grace preachers say that the "will of my father" refers to "believe in Christ", but that seems to be going in circles as we forget that those people condemned already did address Jesus as "Lord" before they were condemned. 

Or the lukewarm Christians in Revelations that Jesus said he will spit out of his mouth. Who is it? It's hard to know who they even are. If this is about sinners, lukewarm should be better than cold. But if this is about mixing law with grace, why would those who mix law with grace be spitten out since "cold" by analogy should refer to Pharisee-like people who think of keeping the whole law, while they are implicated to still be accepted by Jesus?

If you think you can answer all of these questions and around 33 extras, I'll happily pile them onto you so you can solve it for me and tell me which parts of the Word I can trust. But if not, and that applies to some preachers whom I consulted who got stumped, you better not stand on the sidelines and say "read the Word" as if it's an easy task.

I admit JonPaul got my exam wrong today-it wasn't science-it's law. But so what? It could have easily been due to mental suggestion from my mention of pixels, or from the fact that he speaks to God about science all the time. But he would seriously have to be a serious hallucinator to come up with searching my name in Hebrew and telling me it means "He has heard". If he were demon possessed and wanted to preach the false doctrine to me, demon would have made sure he got my exam subject right. But the Lord said through him "it is by Christ and not what your exam is that you are saved".

Response to Simon:

You have pointed out a very important issue (and very BIG problem) in evangelical theology.  Not only do evangelicals believe that God tells them in their hearts who to marry, which job to take, what city to live in, which church to attend, and divine personalized guidance in every other aspect of life, evangelicals believe that God reveals to them in their hearts, the true interpretation of Scripture.  Problem is, God seems to give a different interpretation of Scripture to every individual evangelical Christian!  Thus the plethora of evangelical denominations and sects with varying doctrines and beliefs.

I am not going to tell you what my opinion is on the issue of eternal security.  But here is my suggestion on how you and every Christian can learn the true Christian position on this issue:  Read all the passages of Scripture that discuss this issue, both those that seem to support "once saved, always saved" and those that seem to support that a true believer, a true Christian, CAN turn his back on Christ, abandon his faith, and lose his salvation.

Once you have looked at all these verses, take a look at the beliefs on this issue of the Early Christians.  What did the Christians of the first four centuries after Christ believe on this doctrine?  I know that many Baptists and evangelicals believe that the true Faith ceased to exist after the last Apostle died, but how can that be true when God said that the gates of Hell would not prevail against his Church?

The early Christians had a very clear position on this issue.  I suggest you look into it.  The writings of the early Christian do NOT have the same level of authority of Scripture, but their writings can help us to understand how the disciples of the Apostles understand the passages of Scripture that discuss "eternal security".

Martin Luther taught that the Bible is the only SUPREME authority.  Tradition, Church councils and popes do not have the same authority as Scripture.  However, Luther did NOT teach that the writings of the early Christians have NO authority.  This is the mistake that many evangelicals make.  They disregard all the copious writings of the early Christians, and instead listen for a voice inside them to tell them what this 2,000 old document, written in ancient languages, in a Middle Eastern culture, means to say.

Gary, you make some good points. I understand the respect that needs to be present when we talk about hearing from God and how if we don't handle it correctly it can lead to problems. I myself spend a lot of time preparing people for some of the unexpected difficulties that arise when learning to hear from God. You have listed many reasons why the "God speaks to me" card can be misused. But, have you not considered the good that also comes through hearing God's voice?

I know a man who was told by God to stand on his head in front of a drink machine at a gas station. Three times the man refused to listen by finally he pulled over his car and stood on his head in front of the station drink machine. The worker behind the counter began to cry, so my friend who has stood on his head went over to the guy and asked him what was going on. Well twenty minutes earlier, a christian had come into the store and talked to the worker about giving his life to the Lord. The man refused to and said, "The day a man stands on his head in front of that cooler will be the day I give my life to God."

Because this man heard the personal voice of God inside and stood on his head, that worker gave his life to Christ! He is now a saved Christian. 

I have seen dozens of people's lives encouraged and changed because of words God has given me for others as well as many stories from my friends who lead people to the Lord or healed people with sicknesses or infirmities through following the voice of the spirit. 

I do agree and throughly understand your point that hearing God's voice can have be messy, but I believe the risk is worth it. So much good comes from hearing God that it outweighs the problems we may or may not have.

I like that you don't want people's lives to be frozen and confused in waiting for God to say something, and I like that you want to Bible to be our chief authority and you even recommend reading the early apostles writings to help understand the scriptures. I have no debates with you over that. 

I think what I hear you saying is that we shouldn't try to hear from God because it isn't provable and reliable and people have the opportunity to use that weakness however they want. 

Have you ever heard the story of the boy who cried wolf? A shepard boy pretended two times that wolves were attacking when he was actually safe. However, the third time some wolves did really attack, but because the people thought he was joking they did not come to help and the flock was eaten. 

It seems to me that in your experience when people have said, "God told me," they have been like the shepard boy who was bored and looking for attention. And you have become like one of the townspeople who no longer counts on those words because they have been so misused. However, you may find that one day (which I would say is everyday) God is really going to speak something important and if you are not willing to listen, you may miss out on some opportunities and wonderful things God has for your life. I am sure God will find some other ways to reach you, but when you cut off communication with God, you miss out on the core privilege of your faith, a relationship with Him. 

Yes, hearing God's voice is dangerous, messy, and abused. You cannot always prove what you hear and people can pretend what they want. But God is a God who works in the midst of such chaos and works everything out in conformity with his will. When we learn to cooperate with Him and learn to listen and know Him, we enter into the greatest adventure of life!

I admire your devotion to Christ, my brother, but your belief in personal, internal, divine revelations is the seed of false doctrine, sects, and cults.

I will pray for you, brother, that you will come to see that God's Word contains everything you need to follow Christ. God speaks in a very clear, loud voice...his Holy Word. You don't need to listen for internal voices.

God bless you.

Brother, I have thought about digging through the writings of early church history. They are no use to me-even more contradictions than the Bible. I'd need around 2000 pages of research to try to be convinced biblically without the Holy Spirit. Do you not understand how complex this debate is? Tonnes of books have been pushed into this subject, refuted, re-refuted and so on.

And the major problem again, is ambiguity. Context hardly helps to determine what Jesus meant about those who "turn away" when troubles come. It could mean physically, it could mean spiritually lost forever, but what's the right interpretation? Or again, does the parable of the thorns refer to those whose faith are not prospering them on earth, or does it mean eternal damnation? Everyone says "context is the key" but really, knowing that he's talking to the disciples under a tree after riding a donkey etc-that's not gonna help you interpret these vague scriptures. Game over. No more information. Everyone just interprets these shady scriptures the way they like merely on the basis that it could be interpreted in such a way without expressly being refuted. But this is easy to do. The Bible is so vague that many things can be interpreted in drastically coincidental ways. Know the occultist Edgar Cayce? He interpreted the whole book of Revelation with eastern spirituality and chakra philosophy and it still looked quite profoundly legit, although it's not.

We're normal people with things to do. I for one can't be stuffed doing any further research on what the Bible says. I'm not lazy-I know more Bible than all my friends combined and yet I'm hopeless on the subject. How am I going to study? Put in 8 hours more a day to seek an answer?

And another grace blogspot has something to say about the early church as well http://pureunadulteratedgrace.blogspot.co.nz/2011/09/early-church-history-is-proof-against.html 
I think he has a point, especially that even Universalism was widely accepted among the early Church, how then can we trust them on matters of salvation?

Every evangelist does interpret scripture differently, but I test those who claim to have spoken to God. You got to remember that just because evangelists have different doctrines, it doesn't mean that their interpretation was inspired by the Holy Spirit. JonPaul's detailed descriptions of how God speaks and the beauty of the messages captivated me. A lot of other people who claim to "speak to God" don't even bother explaining what it feels like. A lot of people claim that they have a great personal relationship about God and know for sure they are told by God they are saved, but when I ask them to do a favour and ask God if I'm saved they shiver and stumble. They clearly aren't so sure they speak to God as they boast!

I feel that JonPaul isn't making this up. He has nothing to gain here if he were. Working for demons? Then his website should be way more expansive than just a personal blog-there's plenty of ways to attract more readers without being an inconspicuous spot on the internet, read by online stalkers like us who pay him no prestige, no marketing and no money. Talking about inconspicuousness, it's surprising how hard it is to find this place. I've been researching for months and only ended up here by luck. Or is he trolling? With long words like these that tire himself more than me? Out of pride? If so, why does he constantly admit he mishears stuff? Out of imagination? Then who revealed the science stuff to him? His piece on emotions was more profound than what many psychology students who have studied emotions for years could write. Also, it's easy to imagine sentences, but paragraph after paragraph, active imperatives as well? I don't think JonPaul is fake. I think he's legit. 

You say that the internal voices are best not to be trusted. I agree, on the basis that it would be reasonably possible for one to reach a conclusion based on the Bible. But if I can't, then listening to internal voices don't really have a much higher probability of making me more wrong or confused than I already am. After all, you're stuck with a coin flipping probability either way for both options.

Moreover, the Holy Spirit is supposed to be no less talkative than Jesus. Jesus said "it is good that I am leaving you, otherwise the Holy Spirit will not come". JonPaul seems to fit this scripture. The Holy Spirit should be a discernable force for the Christian. Most of us are treating the Holy Spirit like Ron Weasley's rat Scabbers who does nothing but stay and sleep, even as the hypocrites cry "Christianity is a relationship, not a religion".

Thank you Simon. I do agree that the Bible is unclear at times, but I hope we aren't leaving the tone that it's altogether unreliable. There are scriptures that are pretty clear and lots of people can agree on. But the Holy Spirit is the one who should guide our reading, especially in tricky passages. And I appreciate that you think of me as valid. There may come a time when more research is done and large portions of what I felt came from the Lord is false. Then again, further research may confirm the things I felt I heard. I have had drastic instances of hearing the Lord wrong in my life along with drastic instances of hearing Him right. So why do I risk something so unstable? Why would I write what I feel like the Lord is saying if I can't prove it?

Because even if you mishear God 3 out of 4 times, that 1 time of hearing correctly is worth it. God's words change people's lives and gives them purpose, peace, and life. I have found this as a key to enjoying my christian walk and I hope others will see my boldness as inspiration to learn to hear from God themselves. I don't have any special qualifications. I once struggled to hear even the most basic things, and I still struggle from time to time. I have no degrees in theology, just a passion to know God. Nor am I always a humble person. Christ's love keeps me humble and bold but there are times where I stumble. There is not anything I have that anyone else may have. God doesn't speak to me because I am an 'ideal christian' or someone who 'seeks Him' all the time. He speaks to me because he is my father and I am his son and we are meant to know each other. Likewise I believe he will speak to anyone who is willing to listen.

I want you to be comforted, encouraged, and inspired about the things God says, but don't take everything I claim God said as unquestionable truth. There have been times in my past where I felt strongly that I heard the Lord say something and a year later, I realized was actually not Him. And there have been times where even in the same paragraph I realized I had heard some details correct and others incorrect. I am still working on learning to recognize my own thoughts from His.

I am sorry I did not hear correctly about your class and I'm glad you still have confidence that God wants you to be secure. I have prayed that you begin to hear the Lord's voice for yourself too! And I would be happy to ask the Lord what more he wants to say to you perhaps over email.

"And I would be happy to ask the Lord what more he wants to say to you perhaps over email". Brother that is awesome. My email is kungfusimon@gmail.com. Dude your blog moved me more than all the pastors I listened to combined. You actually care so much for your brothers and dare to just ask God stuff on the spot. Not that pastors don't, but most of them are just "hey come and purchase my dvd" or otherwise saying "God talks to you" while never bothering to give an example themselves. I don't know what I should ask God. I have many curiosities...alien...demons...possessions...black eye kids...biblical verses...swords...architecture of heaven...next week's lotto number...how the new jerususalem can be as tall as it is wide etc but don't worry I'm not going to do that to you hahaha. 

I would be happy if you asked the Lord if I can join the Battle of Armageddon, whether the rapture is pre-tribulation or post tribulation, whether I can have a sword to keep for the rest of eternity and a new name.

Do you loose eternal life those moments you don't walk by the spirit?
Galatians 6:8 "8 Whoever sows to please their flesh, from the flesh will reap destruction; whoever sows to please the Spirit, from the Spirit will reap eternal life."
Do you forfeit your entrance into the kingdom of heaven in those moments you don't walk in the spirit?
Galatians 5:21 "I warn you, as I did before, that those who live like this will not inherit the kingdom of God"

item.title: Katie - 2013-08-02 18:50:12
item.content:encoded:
Hi! I came across your blog while doing a Google search for more info about discerning God's voice. I've read some of what you've written, and I'm wondering if you could answer a question for me and give me a little bit of insight.

I'm trying to figure out how to be completely certain that it's God's voice that I'm hearing. I've followed the "checklists" of making sure what I "heard" lined up with Scripture, produced good fruits, brought peace, etc.; and it does, but I'm still not sure. The reason is that everything in the spiritual seems to confirm that it is God's voice; yet everything I see in the physical confirms that it's NOT His voice. The Bible says that God confirms His word with signs, right? So if this was God's voice, wouldn't the physical start to line up with what I'm hearing? Wouldn't He give signs for assurance?

item.title: David Bartlett - 2013-09-04 02:27:54
item.content:encoded:
Friday night I was laying on the couch talking to God because I wanted to hear his voice.  I prayed.  I cried.  I prayed some more.  I cried some more.  I went online and found a lot of websites that talk about hearing God's voice and none of them gave me any kind of answer, just more rabbit trails.  More goose hunts.

I was recently in a relationship with a man for a couple of months that I grew to care for very deeply.  He broke up with me and when he did the reasons he gave didn't make sense.  The only sense I could make out of it was that he had been stolen.

Before that things had been a little rocky and I heard Joseph Prince say three times that if we are having problems in our relationships we should talk to God not other people, but I was talking to my friends trying to do the best I could in the situation.  I was a man trusting in his own strength.

“Cursed is the man who trusts in man
And makes flesh his strength,
Whose heart departs from the Lord.
6 For he shall be like a shrub in the desert,
And shall not see when good comes,
But shall inhabit the parched places in the wilderness,
In a salt land which is not inhabited.

That was all over 2 months ago now.  Since that time I've had my hope encouraged that God would bring him back, but then I lose faith and hope because of what scripture says about these kinds of relationships.  But every time I think I need to give up and let go and move on, my heart cries and rather than hardening myself to it I wait and a song, or a message, a devotional or a message from Joseph Prince gives me hope that God may not be done with it all yet.

The guy who broke up with me is an atheist.  He won't talk to me anymore.  We used to have a great time together watching movies, playing video games, laughing.  He was my best friend and I liked sending him funny pictures to make him laugh.  And then he was just gone.  Like someone came along and stole him away from me.  And I know it wasn't God because I kept feeling like God was saying talk to me and instead I was talking to my friends.  

I found your website because I was searching on how to hear God again and I'm going to try to listen more to what goes on inside of me after reading your blog about it.  I also read the three parts of what hinders prayers.

Anyway, I didn't really know I would write all this, but just felt compelled to say something after the things you shared because right now I don't have many friends with faith or belief in the kind of grace you wrote about, most of my friends don't have anything at all to do with church.  As for me, my church consists of watching Joseph Prince sunday mornings.  So I just wanted to thank you to your blog posts and wave hello.

Thank you,
-David

item.title: Romans 1-8
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
I have been teaching how it's a good idea to read a book from beginning to end in one sitting to help bring out the context. Well, last night I read a large portion of Romans but not the full book because it got to be too late. I wanted to write a post on my reflections from the book. There are a few different ways of interpreting certain scriptures, but I will share the interpretation I am examining. After his greetings, he sympathizes with the Jewish ideas of Gentiles. That they have rejected the knowledge of God and sought their own ways. However in Romans 2 he points the finger back at the Jews saying,
Therefore you have no excuse or defense or justification, O man, whoever you are who judges and condemns another. For in posing as judge and passing sentence on another, you condemn yourself, because you who judge are habitually practicing the very same things [that you censure and denounce]. (Romans 2:1)
He warns them, that if they have confidence in their flesh (that they uphold the law) they are no better. They are showing contempt for God's kindness to the gentiles not realizing that God's kindness is leading them to repentance. They want the gentiles to be judged. Paul then says,
For He will render to every man according to his works [justly, as his deeds deserve]: To those who by patient persistence in well-doing [springing from piety] seek [unseen but sure] glory and honor and [the eternal blessedness of] immortality, He will give eternal life. But for those who are self-seeking and self-willed and disobedient to the Truth but responsive to wickedness, there will be indignation and wrath. (Romans 2:6-8)
This is the just judgment of God that falls on all human beings alike because of sin. However later in Romans, Paul talks about how God's gift of righteousness protects us from this wrath. It seems to me he is showing us the danger we are in and the humility we are in apart from Christ's forgiveness. Paul talks about how God is impartial, judging both Jews and Gentiles alike. However, in this day the Jews felt a sense of superiority over the Gentiles because they had been entrusted with God's commandments. But Paul says, you who boast in the law, do you do what it says? For even if the gentiles who do not have the law do what it says, their consciences bearing witness, they will condemn you who have the law yet don't practice it! He says, having pride in your law is pointless if you don't keep it! For being a Jew is not a person who is one outwardly, but who is one inwardly. So then his audience raises a question? Then do Jews have any advantage over gentiles? Is there any special benefits to being a Jew? Paul says that they have much favor, to begin with they were entrusted with the words of God!  This next part gets confusing for me. He says,
What if some did not believe and were without faith? Does their lack of faith and their faithlessness nullify and make ineffective and void the faithfulness of God and His fidelity [to His Word]? By no means! Let God be found true though every human being is false and a liar, as it is written, That You may be justified and shown to be upright in what You say, and prevail when You are judged [by sinful men]. (Romans 3:3-4)
I suppose what he is saying in this passage is that, did God not stop entrusting and favoring the Jews because some of them did not follow God. Despite the Jew's lack of faithfulness to their Creator, God's mercy and election was made all the more evident. God was bound by his word so that he could not remove the promises he had given the Jews, even though they betrayed him. Therefore this audience says, "Well if my sin serves to bring out God's unstoppable faithfulness why am I being judged?" They are angry with Paul because they think he is saying that we should do evil that God's goodness towards us may result. Paul says this is not what he teaches and they rightly condemn such beliefs. Then they ask, "Are we Jews better off than the gentiles?" Paul says no, because all men alike are under sin. Therefore the law silences all of us and holds us accountable to God. No man can be made righteous through their human obedience, for the real function of the law was to help people see how sinful they were and make them conscious of sin! But now, God has provided a righteousness completely apart from the law although the law and prophets testify to it. By trusting and relying on Jesus Christ we are freely given this righteousness. We have all sinned and now are justified, made up upright, and in right standing with God completely and only because of his grace. God sent his son, to show his justice. For he had not punished our sins knowing that he would one day punish them in Christ. Thus by punishing Christ, God has justly condemned sin while at the same time justifying the sinner. He remains an honorable judge who can show unlimited mercy to us. Paul then says, so what makes a Jew better than a gentile anymore? Nothing! For man is now justified by faith alone apart from good deeds. Is God merely a God of the Jews or Gentiles also? It is God who justifies the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised by their newly acquired faith. (Circumcision was a distinguishing mark of the Jew). Then he says, "Do we therefore make the law worthless by this faith? No! We are actually serving it's purpose!" The law was not made to justify man, but to hold us accountable to God so that we would come to Christ for justification. By coming to Christ for justification, we are actually fulling what the law was truly intended to do. Abraham himself was not justified by works but by faith. For when he believed God, God counted him as righteous. Now when someone works, his wages are not counted as a gift or favor but as an obligation. But to those who do not work but trust God who justifies the ungodly, their faith is credited to them for righteousness (as a gift). Thus David congratulates the man and blesses those whom God gives righteousness apart from works. "Blessed and happy and to be envied are those whose iniquities are forgiven and whose sins are covered up and completely buried.  Blessed and happy and to be envied is the person of whose sin the Lord will take no account nor reckon it against him." (Romans 4:7-8). What I learned from this, is that God will never count your sin against you or even take it into account anymore! Paul writes, was this blessing meant only to Jews (the circumcised)? Or also the gentiles  (the uncircumcised)? Abraham's faith made him righteous, was this before or after he was circumcised? If it was after he was circumcised, then justification would only belong to the Jews. It was not after, but before! He received the mark of circumcision as an evidence and seal of the righteousness he had while he was still uncircumcised. This means he is the father of all, both Jew and Gentile, who receive righteousness by faith. Later Paul explains that this is symbolic of the Holy Spirit.  We have received righteousness for believing in Christ, and the Holy Spirit circumcises our hearts by dwelling within us and destroying the sinful nature. He is a seal of the righteousness we've been given. For God's promise to Abraham that he would be an heir of the world did not come through obeying the law, but through the righteousness of faith. For if the promises of God come to those who earn them by the obey the law, then faith is made worthless! What value does faith in the Christ's blood have if you must earn God's promises through works? God's promises could never be fulfilled as a gift because no one can do enough good to earn them! Rather our attempts at human made righteousness only incur wrath! But if there is no law, then there is nothing to discredit you from freely receiving the promises! Those words, 'it was accredited to him' was not written to him alone, but for our sakes too! For we all receive this gift of righteousness when we believe in Christ. For Christ was put to death because of our misdeeds and raised to secure our justification, absolving us from all guilt before God. Therefore, since we are justified (absolved of guilt) and God is no longer taking account of our sins, let us grasp that fact and enjoy the peace we have in being reconciled to God through Christ! Through him we have unlimited access by this faith into God's unmerited favor in which we firmly stand. And let us be excited in the hope of experiencing and enjoying the glory of God! Moreover, let us be full of joy now! Even in our sufferings, knowing that persecution shows our unwavering patience and that patience proves our faith is real. And this assurance of faith produces a joyful and confident hope! Such a hope never disappoints us because the Holy Spirit is in us, testifying that we are God's children through pouring God's love into our hearts! For while we were still powerless to overcome sin, at the fitting time, Christ died for all the ungodly. This is an extraordinary thing! For who gives up his life even for an upright man? Though if the man was noble, lovable and generous someone might even dare to die. But God shows and proves his love for us by the fact that when we were at our worst, being controlled by sin, Jesus died for us. Therefore since we are currently justified by Christ's blood, how much more certain is it that we shall be saved through him from the wrath of God? If while we were enemies of God we were saved, how much more now that we are reconciled to God shall we be saved through his life!? Not only this, but we also glory in God's love and perfection through  Jesus Christ whom we have now received and enjoy reconciliation. Sin was introduced to the world though one man, Adam, and death (condemnation) as a result of that sin. So death spread to all men and no one could escape it's power. Sin was in the world before the law was given, but it was not taken into account. Yet, even those who did not break a commandment of God were condemned. Adam was a symbol of Christ, he being destructive, but Christ saving! But God's free gift of righteousness is not even on the same scale as Adam's sin! For many died because of man's offense but much more profusely does God's grace and free gift of undeserved favor that comes through one man Christ abound and overflow for the benefit of many! Nor is Adam's condemnation to be compared with Christ's justification. For Adam was condemned for one single sin, but Christ justifies us despite many sins! For just as through Adam's sin, everyone was condemned, much more surely those who receive God's unmerited favor and free gift of righteousness shall reign as kings in life! The law came in only to increase our condemnation and stir up our sinful nature, but where sin increased God's grace has greatly surpassed it! Just as sin reigned in condemnation, so God's favor reigns through the gift of righteousness which results in eternal life through Jesus. Wait a second... does this mean we should sin so God's grace becomes more apparent? Certainly not! When we died to sin, the flesh that controlled us was destroyed so that we would no longer be slaves to the appetites of the flesh. How could we continue to live in it? It goes against our very nature! When you were baptized, you died with Christ and just as Christ was raised again to live forever, so you will be raised into a new life with new behaviors. Our old (unrenewed) self was nailed to the cross so that it might no longer have sway over us. For when a man dies, he is freed from the power of sin. For Christ died to sin's power once and for all and now lives in unbroken fellowship with God! So don't walk against the nature God has put in you to fulfill the lust of the flesh. Instead offer yourselves to God as though you have been raised to a perpetual life. For sin does not have dominion over you, since you are not under law, but under grace. What then? Shall we sin because we are not under the law but under God's favor and mercy? Certainty not! Don't you know that when you chose to believe in Christ you became slaves to him? Before you were slaves to Adam which resulted in your condemnation. What benefit did you reap then from the things you are now ashamed of? But now that you have becomes slaves to Christ, obedience and righteousness hold sway over your desires and actions! God now works in you what is pleasing to him! So just as you yielded yourself to the temptations of the flesh, now yield yourself to the temptations/promptings of the spirit as servants of righteousness. For when you were slaves to sin, righteousness did not have a pull on your heart. But now that you are set free from sin and have become slaves to God, your present reward is holiness and it's end is eternal life! For sin results in condemnation, but the free gift of God is eternal life through union with Jesus Christ! Don't you know, that the law can only condemn you when you live? A married woman is bound to her husband as long as he lives, but if he dies she is free to marry another. But, if she remarries while her husband lives, she is called an adulteress. The law only binds her while her husband lives so that if she marries after he has passed away, she is not an adulteress. Likewise, you were once married to the law but you died so that now you are free to marry someone else. Now, you are married to Christ who was raised from the dead so that we might bear fruit to God! When we were living out of human effort, the sinful temptations aroused and awakened by the law were constantly operating in us, so that we bore fruit to our condemnation. But now we have been separated from the law which held us in sin by condemnation. Now we no longer serve not under the law, but under obedience to the promptings of the spirit. So is the law identical with sin? No way! Nevertheless, if it had not been for the law, I would not have recognized sin. I would not have had any consciousness or sense of guilt over covertness if the law had not said, "You shall not covet." But sin is very clever. When I was condemned by the law, it found it's opportunity to arouse all kinds of sinful passions and desires in me. For apart from the law, sin is inactive. Once I was doing well, free from condemnation, because I was unconscious of the law. But when I learned the commandment, sin was revived and I was condemned. The very legal ordinance that was supposed to bring life, actually brought death! For sin, taking the opportunity afforded by the commandment cheated me and used the condemnation of the law to kill me. Therefore the law is holy and each commandment is holy just and good. Did the law, which is good, bring condemnation to me? Not at all. It was sin, working condemnation in me by using this good thing as a weapon in order that sin might be shown up clearly to be sin that I might perceive it. I know the law is good, but I am not. I am sold in slavery to sin! I do not understand myself, for I do not do what I wish, but I do the very thing I loathe! Not if I act habitually against my desire, that means I agree that the law is good. However, it is no longer I who is doing the deed, but sin that has possession of me. For nothing good dwells in me, in my flesh. I can will what is right, but I cannot perform it. Now if I do what I do not want to do then it is no longer me doing it, but the principle of sin which dwells within me. So I find this principle at work. When I want to do good, evil is ever present with me and I am subject to it's demands. My new nature delights in God's law, but I also discern in my bodily members the desires of a different principle that wars against my mind making me a prisoner and slave to the law of sin that dwells in my flesh. O how miserable I am! Who will release and deliver me from this body of condemnation? Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then my mind serves God, but my flesh is a slave to sin. Therefore there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus!!! For the principle of the Spirit of life (the principle of my new risen being) has freed me from the principle of sin and condemnation. For God did what the law could not do because my flesh could not carry it out. He condemned his son in the flesh as an offering. Now the demand of the law is fulfilled in us who have risen to a new life that is controlled by the spirit and not the flesh. For those who are controlled by the flesh have their minds set on it's evil desires. They cannot please God! But those who are controlled by the Spirit have their minds set on the things that gratify Him! Now the mind controlled by self effort is constantly condemned and miserable, but the mind controlled by the Spirit brings life and peace! Your human effort, controlled by sin's temptations cannot fulfill God's law. But you are not controlled by the flesh if you have the spirit in you! But if anyone does not possess the Holy Spirit he is not truly a child of God. But if Jesus lives in you, then although your natural body is dead by reason of sin and guilt, the spirit is alive because of the righteousness you have been given. And if the spirit who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you, he will restore life to your mortal body as well! So then, we are helplessly controlled by the Spirit, not to the flesh. So we might as well give in to the spirit's promptings. For those who are controlled by the sinful nature have been condemned, but if through the power of the Holy Spirit you have destroyed the flesh and it's hold over you, you shall really live forever. For all who are led by the spirit of God are sons of God! The spirit that is in you is not a spirit of slavery to put you once more in fear, but you have received the spirit of adoption in the bliss of which we cry "Papa!" The Holy Spirit thus testifies with our spirit, assuring us that we are children of God. And if we are his children, then we are also heirs of God and fellow heirs of Christ, sharing his inheritance with Him! Only we are asked uphold this faith despite suffering so we might share in His glory.
