item.title: Justified by Faith - Paraphrase of Romans
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
This is my humble, loose paraphrase of Romans. I've been studying one of N. T. Wright's articles on Romans, which for an average reader like me was a difficult read. Nevertheless, some of his main concepts came through. I would like to summarize some of the things he said as well as my own observations to the best of my knowledge. I don't guarantee that I understood N. T. Wright completely so this is not a complete reflection on his material, but it is my best attempt. I hope if he read this he would be pleased.

Romans was likely written to proselytes, or gentiles who had converted over to Judaism and then later became Christians. In this time there was a lot of tension between Jews and Gentiles. The Jews were jealous of the Gentiles and didn't see them as equal people of God and the Gentiles were gloating over the Jews because God had accepted them while the Jews had failed in fulfilling their call. Paul's letter to Romans was concentrated on smoothing those tensions.

Paul's opening was a familiar opening to Jews of that day, how the gentiles were part of the problem of sin in the world and how unfaithful Jews were also accountable to that same problem.

This goes back to the overarching story of the Bible. When Adam disobeyed God, he messed up all of creation. Sin became a problem in the world. When Abraham came along, God planned for him to be the Father of the solution to fallen creation. Through Abraham, also Israel, God had planned to set the world to rights, to fix the problem of sin, and to restore creation back to the glory that Adam lost. Israel was given this call and the law was the means by which they would do that, at least as the average Jew thought.

In the first couple chapters of Romans, Paul is explaining how just as the Gentiles were contributing to the problem of sin in creation, the Jews who were called to fix it, were also part of the problem themselves. They had failed in the calling God had given them. This is a problem for God's character. God's faithfulness is in question. If God said he would set the world to rights and Israel was his means by doing that and Israel failed at her task, then what does that say about God's faithfulness? Would God then be found a liar?

This is another one of the overarching arguments in Romans. As N. T. Wright says, when the Bible talks about God's righteousness it is not referring to his merits and good status that he then transfers onto the believer so the believer is counted as though he had done everything that God had, but rather God's righteousness has to do with his own covenant faithfulness. That is not to say that the believer is not given righteousness or made righteous, the believer is made righteous but it is not God's own righteousness which he has.

The word righteous to a jew was associated with a court room. When a case was tried, the judge would declare one person guilty and the other righteous. That is to say, one person broke the covenant, while the other faithfully upheld it. So in the Old Covenant, when we talk about God's righteousness, we are refering to how faithful he is to that covenant, which would have been to take care of his people, to be their God, to punish them when they did wrong but to be patient and tolerant. To show justice and mercy and hear their prayers. These were acts of God's covenant faithfulness. Now in Romans the faithfulness of God is in jeopardy. God planned to set the world to rights through Israel and the law but Israel failed. How then can God be faithful to his covenant?

Romans 3:21 "But now apart from the law the righteousness of God has been made known, to which the Law and the Prophets testify."

That is, the covenant faithfulness of God is now made known apart from the law. By trusting and relying on Jesus Christ we are freely given this righteousness. We have all sinned and now are justified, made upright, and in right standing with God completely and only because of his grace. God sent his son, to show his justice. For he had not punished our sins knowing that he would one day punish them in Christ. Thus by punishing Christ, God has justly condemned sin while at the same time justified the sinner. He remains an honorable judge who can show unlimited mercy to us. Thus God's covenant faithfulness is preserved, because Jesus descends from Abraham and he is in fact the heir of the covenant. Israel's failure served to bring Christ all the more glory. Paul then says, so what makes a Jew better than a gentile anymore? Nothing! For man is now justified by faith alone apart from good deeds. Is God merely a God of the Jews or Gentiles also? It is God who justifies the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised by their newly acquired faith. (Circumcision was a distinguishing mark of the Jew). Then he says, "Do we therefore make the law worthless by this faith? No! We are actually serving it's purpose!" The law was the tool by which the world should have been set to rights, sin should have be dealt with, and creation restored to it's glory. But instead of fulfilling it's purpose, it in fact made sin a bigger problem. Now those who have faith in Christ become partakers in the divine call to restore the world. In Christ, sin has been dealt with and the world now looks forward to a future glory when one day all of creation, humans, beasts, birds, and the land itself will be free from it's bondage to decay.

In Romans 4, the question then becomes, are the Gentiles then Abraham's heirs according to the flesh. Paul's answer was that he was made righteous before he was circumcised, not afterward. He was made righteous when he believed God. This shows that he is the father both of those who are circumcised and those who have faith in Christ. So then gentiles are Abraham's children, not according to the flesh, but according to the spirit, as a divine status and become heirs of the promise.

God had made a promise to Abraham that he would be an heir of the world. What does this mean? I think it means that he would be part of God's plan to restore creation to it's glory. God had made man rulers of this earth and given them a task in the garden. God's plan is that we would once again rule a restored creation and be the people who set it again to rights, but not in the way we might think. We rule through being a servant. Blessed be the meek, blessed be the humble... This promise did not come through obeying the law, but instead came through faith. The law never brought us closer to fulfilling this calling rather it provided God's wrath. But where there is not law, there is no transgression.

Therefore, just as Abraham was made righteous through faith, we too are made righteous through faith. Christ was put to death to deal with our sin once and for all and raised again as a divine signature to show that he was in fact the heir of the promise and the one whom God had intended his covenant to be fulfilled in. For Christ was put to death because of our misdeeds and raised to secure our justification, absolving us from all guilt before God.

Therefore, since we are absolved of guilt, and God is no longer taking account of our sins, let us grasp that fact and enjoy the peace we have with God, since He has accepted us and put us on friendly terms with Him through Christ! Through him we have unlimited access by this faith into God's unmerited favor in which we firmly stand. And let us be excited in the hope of experiencing and enjoying the glory of God! That is the restoration of everything that Adam lost.

Moreover, let us be full of joy now! Even in our sufferings, knowing that persecution reveals our unwavering patience and that patience proves our faith is real. And this assurance of faith produces a joyful and confident hope! Such a hope never disappoints us because the Holy Spirit is in us, testifying that we are God's children through pouring God's love into our hearts! For while we were still powerless to overcome sin, at the fitting time, Christ died for all the ungodly. This is an extraordinary thing! For who gives up his life even for an upright man? Though if the man was noble, lovable and generous someone might even dare to die. When we were at our worst, God could have easily done away with us. But instead, he demonstrates His love towards us by sending his own son in our place! Therefore since we are now justified by Christ's blood, how much more certain is it that we shall be saved through him from God’s wrath? The wrath that will be displayed on the day of judgement when all men are judged for their deeds. If while we were enemies of God we were saved, how much more now that we are his children shall we be saved through his life!? Not only this so, but we also glory in God's love and perfection through Jesus Christ whom we have now received and enjoy reconciliation.

item.title: Justified by Faith - Part 2
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
Sin was introduced to the world though one man, Adam, and death (condemnation) as a result of that sin. So death spread to all men and no one could escape it's power. Sin was in the world before the law was given, but it was not taken into account. Yet, even those who did not break a commandment of God were condemned. Adam was a pattern of Christ, he being destructive, but Christ saving! But God's free gift of righteousness is not even on the same scale as Adam's sin! For many died because of one man's offense but much more profusely does God's grace and free gift of undeserved favor that comes through one man Christ, abound and overflow for the benefit of many! Nor is Adam's condemnation to be compared with Christ's justification. For Adam was condemned for one single sin, but Christ justifies us despite many sins! For just as through Adam's sin, everyone was condemned, much more surely those who receive God's unmerited favor and free gift of righteousness shall reign as kings in life! The law came in only to increase our awareness of sin and stir up it’s movement, but where sin increased, God's grace has greatly surpassed it! Just as sin reigned in condemnation, so God's favor reigns through the gift of righteousness which results in eternal life through Jesus.

Don't misunderstand me. You may think I am saying that we should live a crazy sinful lifestyle so God's grace becomes more apparent. I am certainly not! When we died to sin, the sin that controlled us was destroyed so that we would no longer be controlled by the appetites of the flesh. How could we continue to live in it? It goes against our very nature! When you were baptized, you died with Christ and just as Christ was raised again to live forever, so you will be raised into a new life with new behaviors. Our old (unrenewed) self was nailed to the cross so that it might no longer have sway over us. For when a man dies, he is freed from the influence and penalty of sin. For Christ died to sin's power once and for all and now lives in unbroken fellowship with God! So don't walk against the nature God has put in you to fulfill the lust of the flesh. Instead offer yourselves to God as though you have been raised to a perpetual life. For sin does not have dominion over you, since you are not under law, but under grace.

But what’s to stop us from sinning if we are free from the law and under grace instead?!

Don't you know that when you chose to believe in Christ you became slaves to him? Before you were slaves to Adam which resulted in your condemnation. What benefit did you reap then from the things you are now ashamed of? But now that you have becomes slaves to Christ, righteousness motivates your desires and actions! God now works in you what is pleasing to him! So just as you yielded yourself to the temptations of the flesh, now yield yourself to the promptings of the Spirit as servants of righteousness. For when you were slaves to sin, righteousness did not have a pull on your heart. But now that you are set free from sin and have become slaves to God, your present reward is holiness and it's end is eternal life! For sin has given you nothing but condemnation, but the free gift of God is eternal life through union with Jesus Christ!

Don't you know, that the law can only condemn you when you live? A married woman is bound to her husband as long as he lives, but if he dies she is free to marry another. But, if she remarried while her husband lives, she is called an adulteress. The law only binds her while her husband lives so that if she marries after he has passed away, she is not an adulteress. Likewise, you were once married to the law but you died so that now you are free to marry Another. Now, you are married to Christ who was raised from the dead so that we might bear fruit to God! When we were living out of human effort, the sinful temptations aroused and awakened by the law were constantly operating in us, so that we bore fruit to our condemnation. But now we have been separated from the law which held us captive to those temptations through the power of condemnation. Now we no longer serve under the law, but under obedience to the promptings of the spirit.

So is the law identical with sin? No way! Nevertheless, if it had not been for the law, I would not have recognized sin. I would not have had any consciousness or sense of guilt over covertness if the law had not said, "You shall not covet." But sin is very clever. When I was condemned by the law, it found it's opportunity to arouse all kinds of sinful passions and desires in me. The very legal ordinance that was supposed to bring life, actually brought death! For sin, taking the opportunity afforded by the commandment cheated me and used the condemnation of the law to kill me. Therefore the law is holy and each commandment is holy just and good. Did the law, which is good, bring death to me? Not at all. It was sin, working death in me by using this good thing as a weapon in order that sin might be shown up clearly to be sin that I might perceive it.

I know the law is good, but I am not. I am sold in slavery to sin! I do not understand myself, for I do not do what I wish, but I do the very thing I loathe! Now if I act habitually against my desire, that means I agree that the law is good. However, it is no longer I who is doing the deed, but sin that has possession of me. For nothing good dwells in me, in my flesh. I can will what is right, but I cannot perform it. Now if I do what I do not want to do then it is no longer me doing it, but the principle of sin which dwells within me. So I find this principle at work. When I want to do good, evil is ever present with me and I am subject to its’ demands. My new nature delights in God's law, but I also discern in my bodily members the desires of a different principle that wars against my mind making me a prisoner and slave to the principle of sin that dwells in my flesh. O how miserable I am! Who will release and deliver me from this body of death? Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then my mind serves God, but my flesh is a slave to sin.

Therefore there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus!!! For the principle of the Spirit of life (the principle of my new risen being) has freed me from the principle of sin and condemnation. For God did what the law could not do because flesh could not carry it out. He condemned his son in the flesh as an offering. Now the demand of the law that we be in right standing with God is fulfilled in us who have risen to a new life that is prompted by the spirit and not the flesh. For those who are controlled by the flesh have their minds set on it's evil desires. They cannot please God! But those who are controlled by the Spirit have their minds set on the things that gratify Him! Now the mind controlled by the flesh is constantly condemned and miserable, but the mind controlled by the Spirit brings life and peace! Your human effort, controlled by sin's temptations cannot fulfill God's law. But you are not controlled by the flesh if you have the spirit in you! But if anyone does not possess the Holy Spirit he is not truly a child of God. But if Jesus lives in you, then although your natural body is dead by reason of sin and guilt, the spirit is alive because of the righteousness you have been given. And if the spirit who raised Jesus from the dead lives in you, he will restore life to your mortal body as well! So then, we are helplessly controlled by the Spirit, not the flesh. So we might as well give in to the Spirit's promptings. For those who are controlled by the sinful nature have been condemned, but if through the power of the Holy Spirit you have destroyed the flesh and it's hold over you, you shall really live forever.

For all who are led by the Spirit of God are sons of God! The Spirit that is in you is not a spirit of slavery to put you once more in fear, but you have received the spirit of adoption in the bliss of which we cry "Papa!" The Holy Spirit thus testifies with our spirit, assuring us that we are children of God. And if we are his children, then we are also heirs of God and fellow heirs of Christ, sharing his inheritance with Him! Only we are asked to uphold this faith despite suffering so we might share in His glory.

item.title: A Unconcerned Dad
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
I have an amazing dad! When I was born, I had a terrible condition that would have killed me, but my dad paid a few million dollars for a treatment that worked. Ever since then, I feel the need to tell everybody. After that he wrote me a book of everything he wanted to say to me and for the next couple months and paid some of our bills for recovery. That's when I understood why he doesn't want to talk to me anymore because whenever I want to hear his voice I go and read the book he wrote me. It doesn't really bother me that he's not around anymore. No, he didn't die, but he just thinks our family will get along well enough without his help. I don't think he needs to be paying the bills for our home, my mother is already working three jobs to make ends meet. I once thought about asking him to help, but then I realized that would be selfish. I should really be focusing on telling everyone what he did. Yes, me and my dad have a great relationship and his book told me that when I was old enough to live on my own we would get to see each other again. There is a theology that has gone around which says that God said everything he needed to in the Bible and did miracles to validate that ministry and then after it had caught on, backed off from the world and no longer gave interest. That argument is not a scriptural one. From the beginning of Genesis to the end of Revelation God was speaking to his people. That argument against God's involvement in this world is based on one obscure passage.
1 Corinthians 13:8 Love never fails. But where there are prophecies, they will cease; where there are tongues, they will be stilled; where there is knowledge, it will pass away. For we know in part and we prophesy in part, but when completeness comes, what is in part disappears. When I was a child, I talked like a child, I thought like a child, I reasoned like a child. When I became a man, I put the ways of childhood behind me. For now we see only a reflection as in a mirror; then we shall see face to face. Now I know in part; then I shall know fully, even as I am fully known.
Actually the argument is not rooted in scripture. It's very hard to twist this passage to say God no longer does these things today. Those who advocate that view said it was there to validate that message. My question is, did we stop preaching that message? Does this message no longer need to be validated? The argument is not based on scripture but experience. Some people have not experienced hearing God's voice, healings, gifts, or miracles so they conclude God doesn't do them. And even that argument is sometimes worthless. For they do not consider many of miracles that happen on a daily basis all across America especially in California at Redding. No rather, when they hear of experiences like these they reject them or take offense at them.
Matthew 13:53-58 "When Jesus had finished these parables, he moved on from there. Coming to his hometown, he began teaching the people in their synagogue, and they were amazed. “Where did this man get this wisdom and these miraculous powers?” they asked. “Isn’t this the carpenter’s son? Isn’t his mother’s name Mary, and aren’t his brothers James, Joseph, Simon and Judas? Aren’t all his sisters with us? Where then did this man get all these things?” And they took offense at him. But Jesus said to them, “A prophet is not without honor except in his own town and in his own home.” And he did not do many miracles there because of their lack of faith.
I believe the problem here was they took offense at Jesus for who he claimed to be. This offense prevented them from experiencing the miracles Jesus wanted to do among them. If people take offense at the idea of God speaking today or doing miracles, I may not be surprised to find that their church does not see as many miracles. Why would Jesus give them something they would only take offense at? But my purpose in writing this article was to rebuke that teaching and help people who've innocently grown up under it to see it for what it is. I hate being offense or rude, but sometimes it's important to offend people for their own benefit.

item.title: How God sees you
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
In religious systems there can be a lot of confusion about how God sees you. And I can understand why. We've not been taught how to distinguish the new covenant from the old. Because of that shift, God relates to us on different terms and some of the ways he related to people under the old covenant are no longer how he relates to us. Does that mean God is a different person? No, God stays the same yesterday, today, and forever. He was faithful to his covenant and a just judge. He judged Israel fairly. But God's justice is satisfied when Christ came and took the judgement you should have deserved. And because he has adequately punished sin, he remains a just God who can show unlimited mercy to his children. Because of what Christ did, you are no longer identified in Adam but in Jesus and you have become holy and blameless in his sight. Listen to how God describes the new covenant. But in fact the ministry Jesus has received is as superior to theirs as the covenant of which he is mediator is superior to the old one, since the new covenant is established on better promises.
Hebrews 8:7-13 "For if there had been nothing wrong with that first covenant, no place would have been sought for another. But God found fault with the people and said : “The days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will make a new covenant with the people of Israel and with the people of Judah. It will not be like the covenant I made with their ancestors when I took them by the hand to lead them out of Egypt, because they did not remain faithful to my covenant, and I turned away from them, declares the Lord. This is the covenant I will establish with the people of Israel after that time, declares the Lord. I will put my laws in their minds and write them on their hearts. I will be their God, and they will be my people. No longer will they teach their neighbor, or say to one another, ‘Know the Lord,’ because they will all know me, from the least of them to the greatest. For I will forgive their wickedness and will remember their sins no more.” By calling this covenant “new,” he has made the first one obsolete; and what is obsolete and outdated will soon disappear." Hebrews 10:9-18 "He sets aside the first to establish the second. And by that will, we have been made holy through the sacrifice of the body of Jesus Christ once for all. Day after day every priest stands and performs his religious duties; again and again he offers the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins. But when this priest had offered for all time one sacrifice for sins, he sat down at the right hand of God, and since that time he waits for his enemies to be made his footstool. For by one sacrifice he has made perfect forever those who are being made holy. The Holy Spirit also testifies to us about this. First he says: “This is the covenant I will make with them after that time, says the Lord. I will put my laws in their hearts, and I will write them on their minds.” Then he adds: “Their sins and lawless acts I will remember no more.” And where these have been forgiven, sacrifice for sin is no longer necessary."
Did you hear that? You have been made holy forever by Jesus's sacrifice. You are perfected and God remembers your sins no more. I remember times when I've talked to the Lord and said, "Did you forgive me for that sin I committed?" The Lord would reply, "What sin?" David says the same thing and is quoted in Romans.
Romans 4:4-8 "Now to the one who works, wages are not credited as a gift but as an obligation. However, to the one who does not work but trusts God who justifies the ungodly, their faith is credited as righteousness. David says the same thing when he speaks of the blessedness of the one to whom God credits righteousness apart from works: 'Blessed are those whose transgressions are forgiven, whose sins are covered. Blessed is the one whose sin the Lord will never count against them.'"

item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
My heart has been concerned and somewhat grieved to hear how some of us relate to God. I want to focus on people who've grown up in a passionate, "sold out for God" youth group where people have fallen absolutely in love with the Lord.

I grew up in one of those youth groups. It changed my life and gave me an abiding love for the Lord that will never go away. It's so wonderful!

But even as I learned and realized so many wonderful things that transformed the way I saw God, the years to come showed me that I had to unlearn a few things as well.

I love it when people show displays of their dedication, passion, and love for the Lord. They'll fast for weeks, pray on their faces for hours, stay up all night to call for more of God's presence and spirit and revival. It's their PDA. Public displays of affection.

I'm sure the Lord appreciates it too. And those people do that from the heart as did I.

The difficulty however is this. In their passion, they miss how easy it is to relate to God and they make it complicated. They make it hard on themselves to be pleasing to God. For instance, they will pray on their faces all night for God's presence to come into their lives and church. Why is that sad? Isn't that awesome? Well yes it is awesome, but it's sad that they don't realize that they already have it. Or that God gives much more freely than that. And some people fell like if they don't keep that dedication up and maintain it, God looses interest in them. And when they realize that they can't live that way all the time, they fear that God will become distant from them. They've set up a standard by which God is pleased with them and wants to be friends and their faith is discouraged because they are not meeting that standard. A number of those people I have meet are very concerned and worried about not being as passionate about the Lord and showing it all the time. If they are not feeling as passionate about God they feel like God is no longer as interested in them. Am I making any sense?

I wish their passion was not wasted on trying to attain something they have been freely given. I wish their passion was used to enjoy the kindness of the Lord and spread it to others.

 

Imagine that you had a friend who gave you a long speech filled with passion on how he wants to hear you speak or just to say a word to him. He wants to give you all he has and beg you to speak to him. Wouldn't you feel concerned? Wouldn't you just want to say, "Why are you doing this? Don't you know I want to speak to you? You don't have to offer me any of those things, I want to speak, it's not that hard."

I think God feels that same sense of compassion.

Those people don't realize how close God already is, but they really want him to be. So they think, if I show such a display of affection that shows how "sold out" I am, won't then God notice my love for him and come close to me?

Their passion is good, but it's misguided.

item.title: Kathleen Angela - 2014-04-01 14:55:12
item.content:encoded:
Hello,  I just discovered your blog and find it very liberating.  I'm quite a bit older than you and have been a Christian for many year's but yet do not feel close to God.  I believe much of it has to do with the way I view Him (legalistic).  I know we are supposed to put Him first, but I find it hard to do so as I feel condemned most of the time.  I also suffer from obsessive compulsive disorder which mainly manifests itself around everything I enjoy being sin.  For example, I've always been interested in fashion/style and have a large collection of magazines reflecting this interest (Vogue, In Style, and fashion catalogs from department stores).  I do try to be selective in that I don't read Cosmo or other such publications.  I guess you could say it is my hobby.  I realize there is not much one would call redeeming in these periodicals; however, they have not affected me negatively in the sense of wanting to be model skinny or dress in a provocative manner.  I just enjoy style and am often complimented on my sense of fashion.  The problem is that I feel guilty because it is hard for me to part with them.  I read or heard somewhere that anything one cannot part with is an idol.  Consequently, whenever I go through a trial, I feel it is God disciplining and/or punishing me for being unable to give up these things.  I have, on occasion, thrown them away, but then felt anger toward God and, consequently, went on to build more collections.  I just read and printed your post on God's discipline and can say it helped a lot.  Can you comment on what I've written?  I just want to feel closer to Him and put Him first but, as I've said, it's been a challenge.

Thanks much,
Kathleen

item.title: How much time have you spent with God?
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
This is perhaps a question we are asking ourselves quite a bit. Especially in churches that talk a lot about the Holy Spirit, one thing that gets strongly emphasized is having a daily quiet time with God.

As much as I see it's value and importance, I know I have felt a lot of guilt and pressure from this question and I know many of my close friends have felt this way as well. Spending time with God changes our lives, it is the basis for Christian living. It is extremely important, and I want to encourage it with all my heart. So why do we find ourselves having a hard time finding enough time or motivating ourselves to spend time with God?

That's a question I'm asking myself at times. Sometimes, I get focused on something else I need to be doing and before I know it, it's been a few days and I haven't sat down and spent any dedicated time with Him. And when I finally do, I have to vent my frustration and guilt over not reaching Him sooner.

But the Lord always has an encouraging word.

"Are you still basing your relationship with me on how much time you spend with me?"

This challenges the way I see spending time with God. I felt like God began comparing our relationship to the relationship of a close friend.

When you have a close friend, do you have to talk everyday to maintain your friendship? Don't you have friends who you only talk to every few weeks or months and yet when you talk you pick up right where you left off? And when you spend time with your friends, do you always do the same things? Do you only talk? Or do you sometimes go watch a move together? Maybe you play music, go on a walk, work on a project, find something unique that you are both interested in, invest in a hobby or sport, perhaps, you play a bored or video game together.

The point is, when you spend time with your friend, you don't always do the same thing every time. (Of course, if you live far apart, talking may be the main option.) And there are seasons in which you and your close friend spend a whole lot of time together and there are times when both of you are busy with other things and you go a long time without speaking. Does this mean the friendship can't survive?

If you felt a pressure to call that friend every morning at a certain time even when you didn't want to or didn't have time, that relationship wouldn't last very long would it? You would begin to resent that friendship. (Unless of course you enjoyed talking every morning). There is a level of spontaneity that is acceptable and needed in every friendship, permission to have a break from each other and permission to plan things on the spur of the moment.

I like what my friend John Long had to say about our daily quiet time. "If you ask a typical christian how much time you should be spending with God, you will get the answer, 'A little bit more.'"

With God, there will be seasons when you spend a whole lot of time together, focused learning and discovering more about Him, and there are seasons when you are both content with each other and coast along enjoying each other's company.

And sometimes we feel a pressure to always be growing deeper with God. Would that work with a spouse? If everyday you needed to find something new about your spouse to be content with your relationship would it work? Aren't there times when you and your spouse are content with one another and coast along enjoying each other's company. And maybe after a time of rest you pick up where you left off and begin to rediscover each other again? Relationships need time to grow and time to rest, both are important.

And why must our time with God always look the same every time? When me and God spend time together I don't always just talk with Him. Sometimes I ask what he wants to do. He has suggested that I program a website and he will assist me. He has encouraged me to write blog articles or listen to a sermon. He may have me research something in the Bible or sometimes we just watch a movie together and he comments on it. Our time together doesn't always have to look the same but whatever we do, we do not do alone. If I program, he is there giving advice. If we watch a film, he is giving his thoughts on it. If we listen to a sermon, we will talk about it afterward.

Spending time with God does not have to always look like shutting your door and spending focused time praying and talking. That can sometimes be needed, but if you realize that God wants to be involved in every part of your life, you will be able to spend time with Him wherever you go and whatever your situation is. If you are in the middle of taking a test, ask God for the answers. Hahahaha, is that cheating? I'm not sure, but the Lord has done that for me.

My second point is this, that we do not need to be treating spending time with God as a chore that needs to be done. It's a relationship and it should be something we want to do. And if you are finding that you don't enjoy it as much as you should or if you are finding that you don't have the time or motivation to spend time with God, you shouldn't try to fix it with your own strength using more effort. Get God involved immediately and ask him to help you enjoy your relationship more and find more time. Don't be ashamed. I know we would rather God not know we are not as interested in spending time with him, but God is the Doctor. And when you are sick you do not run away from the doctor, but towards him. Even enjoying God, and spending time with Him, is something that is carried out through the power of the spirit, and not just our own determination and effort.

God has never stopped showing me grace when I haven't spent much time with Him. He's always just as happy to hear from me and we pick up where we left off, best friends. He's not wanting you to relate to him on a performance scale, thinking that He likes you depending on how much time you've spent with Him. So treat God like a friend and let him be gracious to you. Do not worry about how much time you are or are not spending and instead enjoy the time you do share together and trust in his spirit to help you find more time with him.

item.title: What pleases God?
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
Wow! N T Wright.

“He's a master theologian. If you can understand his readings you can understand the best of them.”

God?

“Yea?”

Did he get it right?

“He is catching the big picture.”

God, does the law inspire sin? Does it cause us to sin?

“You heard him say the law binds you to Adam.”

Yes?

“The law identifies you with your sinful nature, the old self, Adam. It convicts you of who you are apart from me.”

So does that cause us to sin?

“Your actions come from your identify, or who you believe yourself to be. That's the basis of a habit. Habits, and I'm talking about sinful habits, are developed when a person identifies his nature after the sin he commits. Instead of seeing himself as sanctified, holy, and separate from those mistakes, he thinks that is all he is capable of.”

So, what is the correct way. What should I do after I sin?

“Thank God you will not receive your just penalty. You need to turn you eyes back to God and your affections back to him, reminding yourself and strengthening yourself in his grace. Jon Paul, when you let go of grace, sin becomes attractive.”

But doesn't the spirit keep us from sin?

“Yes, but don't forget he is called the spirit of grace. The law works in the opposite spirit, it convicts of sin. As such you cannot live successfully under both. What the law cannot do the spirit is well able.”

Does the spirit just produce everything the law says we should do anyways?

“The way of the spirit is life and peace. You will find mercy in his steps. The law is primitive compared to the spirit. The law deals only with external show, it does not deal with the heart. The Spirit works in you what is pleasing in my sight, from the inside out, provided you continue in my grace.”

But don't people do amazing works through fear of punishment?

“The motivation is not the same. I want to see my children giving gratefully and cheerfully. Giving in fear is not pleasurable to me, just as it wouldn't be to you. Would you want your friends to do nice things for you because they were afraid of you?”

No Lord, that would feel lonely.

“And for a God who identifies himself as being love, that is blasphemy of my character. Fear may look good on the outside, but it is awful on the inside. Whenever you hear a ministry that preaches through fear, run. You cannot have confidence in God's word or love towards you if you operate under fear based preaching.”

So how... how do I not live under the law? It says not to murder, and I really can't get away from not murdering.

“I think you are taking this too literally. The goal is not to prove that those commandments are bad. Practically what it means to no longer be under law is to no longer be under the condemnation of the law. When you do good, be satisfied. When you fail, don't look to the law for encouragement, it will give up on you. Instead listen to the Spirit of grace. He will tell you your true name and will guide you gently.”

Should I still aspire to everything the law says?

“If by that you mean should you not murder then I would say yes.”

But things like circumcision no? I mean, some of the commandments are outdated right?

“No longer in effect? Yes, some of them in fact insult me.”

O yea. So how do I know which ones I should aspire to?

“Jon Paul, the law is no longer your guide. It cannot tell you all the fine print of what I love, that's why I wrote it on your heart. If you want to please me, you won't find a long list of do's and don'ts. You will find a heart that is grateful and wants to show it.”

Wow.

“Paul did give long lists, and I do love all of those. But do you think he told you everything I love? My point is there is not a list long enough for you to memorize. You must trust the daily guidance of the Spirit.”

Thanks God!

“Good night dear child. I love you, and I will put my love in your heart. But I want you to remain in my grace so that it can produce it's full effect in your life.”

item.title: Teaching Grace
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
I've been noticing that the grace movement has become a lot more popular than it was in these past two years. I'm seeing people creating blogs, studying scripture for themselves, and finding speakers being more bold to talk about God's grace.

I wanted to share some advise to my young fellow grace preachers that I've learned from my own experience teaching grace these past 4 years. Again, I'm by no means an expert, and this advise is coming from my own mistakes, some of which you may notice in my articles.

I think all of us have had our lives changed in powerful ways and we've found so much more joy and freedom in our relationships with God and each other. Most of us probably if not all of us have also found that instead of turning to a life of sin after hearing this message we found ourselves bearing good fruit with sincere hearts in joy. I believe this message is correct, because I see it in the scriptures, I hear it from the Lord personally, and I see it bearing good fruit in my life and in the lives of others.

I say all this, because I want to give you confidence in what you teach so that you will not be discouraged when you come against opposition. Sometimes I've felt a great burden of proof or having to be convincing to others who didn't see things the same way I did. I have learned some things from these experiences that I want to share with you. Again, I'm by no means an expert, these are just some things on my heart.

When people object to the grace movement, it's not always a legalistic mentality. People have been brought up their whole lives with the Bible being explained one way and they derive their beliefs from how they interpret the Bible. This means those of us who are passionate about teaching need to understand and respect their viewpoint and not judge them because they don't see things the way we do. I at first opposed the message of grace myself and thought it was blasphemous. We need to be gracious about teaching grace, something that was and somewhat still is hard for me now that I've become so passionate about it.

My second point is that teachers need to avoid alienating people due to misunderstanding. We may say something like, "Since Christ obeyed the law perfectly, our obedience doesn't matter anymore!" I think it is to be understood that we mean, "Since Christ faithfully fulfilled the covenant, we are made righteous and therefore God is no longer assessing us based on our works!" (Or something like that) Often times we use language that is not easily understood to an audience that is not familiar with the grace message and we end up offending them or alienating people who under different circumstances would appreciate the message.

I can't tell you how many people I offended because I was using language that didn't make sense or didn't convey what I meant. And I have to reinterpret a lot of statements with some of the pastors I love to listen to. When you've heard their entire viewpoint, you can understand that they aren't intending to mean certain things when they say some phrases. However, someone who is hearing for the first time will likely face confusion or be turned off by the message. For instance, when we say we are no longer under the law, we also need to be careful to explain why this does not promote sin. Unfortunately, a lot of people who do use grace for immorality have used that same phrase to mean that any sin you want to do is now acceptable and good with God. We want to avoid coming across that way to listeners.

My final point is that teachers need to represent scripture accurately and according to the way it was intended to be conveyed as best they can. This is not specific to grace preachers, I have seen this in part from every denomination. It is especially true of myself. Sometimes when we become passionate about something, we like to reinterpret everything we read to mean what we are passionate about. If we want to be convincing however to people we speak to, then we need to be upholding scripture objectively and with integrity so people can trust the things we say. Have you ever been in a really good sermon in which everything was very powerful and true but at one point the pastor takes a Bible verse and completely misinterprets it to fit his viewpoint? It destroys the trust you have in what he's saying and it's hard not to question other things he says. You may ask yourself, if he's twisting this scripture to fit his viewpoint, is he twisting other scriptures to?

There are areas in the Bible that are just plain confusing for everyone and I don't think anyone understands those passages perfectly. But we want to be humble and be willing to challenge our ideas, to ask hard questions, and change our views if necessary. I believe the Bible at it's core does teach grace, and that's why I am not so afraid to do this. Whatever confusion I fall into, I will eventually, with the Lord's help, fall back into grace.

Especially if we are claiming to represent the true gospel, a gospel that has been understood and misunderstood in previous years, and we are claiming to be speaking what Paul truly intended, we put on ourselves a heavier responsibility to represent well what we teach. And honestly, I think those are too great of titles for anyone to bear. We are trying our best just like previous generations, but if we want to stand out, we should encourage ourselves to be objective, studious, and take time to see the argument from both sides.

And honestly, I don't know why I have the audacity to say this stuff to my readers when I still do the same things myself (of course not intentionally). I guess I see the importance for myself and others and I'm training myself to think more carefully about how I see the Bible. That's why I like to study scholars like N. T. Wright, David Bivin, and others to see if there's any embarrassing misinterpretations I may be about to make in trying to uphold scripture.

So, please don't be discouraged by my advise, it's there to help your teaching be more effective. And you don't have to understand the scripture perfectly in order to teach, no one does and we all have things on our hearts we need to share. Perhaps, the lesson is to be more clear when we communicate, more respectful of others, and more humble in our instruction. Let's make it easy for people to see things from our point of view and pay attention to ourselves so we don't put stumbling blocks in other people's way.

So I ask for your grace myself, I know I still do this, though I don't intend to or want to. I hope to represent the scripture as best as I know how and I know my fellow grace preachers do as well.

item.title: Giving the Devil a Foothold
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
I grew up in a non-denominational/charismatic background and have recycled the same teachings and theology for about 19 years. In these past few years I was introduced to several other churches and denominations. And now upon returning to visit some of my old non-denominational churches I've found that I don't see some things the same way I used to.

There are some things that are wonderful about being in a non-denominational church. Rich, genuine, free worship from the heart. The tangible presence of God (more so celebrated and observed than in some other denominations), the gifts of the spirit, and spiritual passion, pursuit, and hunger for God, and belief that God is active in the world today and wants to bless us. On top of that, leaders typically don't like to get into routines and instead leave lots of room for the Holy Spirit's guidance, whether that means skipping the sermon to worship longer, or praying or speaking longer etc... Most people I meet there have genuine relationships with God and let their lives be guided by his spirit and words.

Speaking then as a fellow charismatic, I've noticed some of the popular beliefs that get circled through many types of non-denominal/charismatic churches that cause a great deal of confusion and pain in my life and has lead to a subtle form of spiritual chaos and odd behavior in these circles, that once to me was normal and now I actually find somewhat disturbing.

I have a lot of compassion for my home denomination as I am all too familiar of how the basic teachings affected my life and how the Lord has guided me out of some of them. If I had to summarize those views I would basically describe them as taking old covenant theology and spiritualizing it. Keep in mind, I don't mean any harm or offense to my companions, rather my heart has been yearning to see freedom hit these areas and I do so humbly.

It's easy to understand how this could be done actually. Some areas of the Bible can be tricky to discern and most of the people in these circles have not been taught to clearly distinguish between the new and the old covenant. So we take these old covenant principles and spiritualize them in a special kind of spiritual rule or experience in order to make them relevant. This can be said about tithing, generational curse, spiritual strongholds and bondage.

However the one I heard today and want to focus on is the legal right of the enemy to invade and bring harm to your life.

It is a pretty widespread belief that when you sin you are opening the door for the enemy to cause chaos in your life. Thus our sin gives the enemy spiritual permission to cause terrible events in our lives. Part of the inner-healing ministry involves breaking this right the enemy has by confessing sin and forgiving people who have sinned against us.

item.title: Trusting in the Flesh
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
I have been visiting different churches in my area, looking for a church that teaches with a grace-perspective lens. Not necessarily one I completely agree with, just one that has a decent grasp on justification completely by faith and not being under the law or any curses. One of the messages I often hear is the 'do more' message. I'm not going to write my perspective on that message right now, but I am going to point out why I think we find that kind of preaching so widespread. It originates with how we interpret the words of Jesus.  I am convinced the idea that law and grace are mixed originated from a misunderstanding of the gospels. The idea of conditional salvation also, I believe, originated there. And it is not surprising! I often wonder why Jesus said some of the things he did and how I should interpret them.
Matthew 5:29 "If your right eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to be thrown into hell."
Notice the simple logic in this passage. Those who stumble perish in hell. What example does he give of 'stumble?' Fall away from the faith? Not even that dramatic! For looking at a woman lustfully! People who teach the 'do more' message are not doing so out of their own invention or trying to go against the doctrine of justification by faith, rather they are just struggling to understand what Jesus meant. And this makes it frustrating for me as I'm studying, because at this point, I don't know enough or see enough to explain why Jesus said everything he did. I have a theory, but that theory needs more testing. I am praying that the Lord will give me understanding and am hoping to find some evidence to explain it's interpretation. In the meantime, I stumbled upon this sermon by John Piper that... in 20 years of going to church have never heard the likes of. I have never heard such a powerful and grace-convicting sermon. It moved me to tears and helped explain something I had been struggling to understand for years, how not to put confidence in my flesh. You can stop reading this post now and just listen to it, you do not need to finish this post if you listen to it. I am condensing and emphasizing one point he made in my own way for those of you who don't have an hour to listen. http://www.desiringgod.org/conference-messages/did-jesus-preach-the-gospel-of-evangelicalism In my mind, I knew before we were saved we shouldn't put confidence in our flesh because we had the sinful nature. But after we were saved, I wondered if we were supposed to have confidence in our flesh, because it was the Holy Spirit producing those works in us and we were given a new nature. The matter got complicated further when realizing that grace causes sin to loose dominion over us. So if I have a new nature that is supposed to live differently, God's own spirit living inside of my heart and motivating my heart and actions to serve him, and I'm under an amazing grace that makes me grateful and produces good fruit in my life. Well then... am I then supposed to trust my flesh? According to the words of Jesus. No. Not even when everything is going for me. Not when I am at the top of my game, grateful, guided by the Spirit, and fully alive. What do I mean by trusting in my flesh? I don't mean depending on it for salvation or being right with God. I wasn't doing that. I mean having confidence and trusting in my performance for relating to God and expecting that to be stable. The message of grace is not perfectionism under disguise. What do I mean by that? Knowing grace doesn't make you perfect in behavior. I think that a gracious understanding and gratefulness will motivate the heart in a far greater measure than any amount of law, but even with this blessing, we should not make the mistake of putting trust in our flesh.
Luke 18:9-14 "Then Jesus told this story to some who had great confidence in their own righteousness and scorned everyone else: “Two men went to the Temple to pray. One was a Pharisee, and the other was a despised tax collector. The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed this prayer: ‘I thank you, God, that I am not a sinner like everyone else. For I don’t cheat, I don’t sin, and I don’t commit adultery. I’m certainly not like that tax collector! I fast twice a week, and I give you a tenth of my income.’ “But the tax collector stood at a distance and dared not even lift his eyes to heaven as he prayed. Instead, he beat his chest in sorrow, saying, ‘O God, be merciful to me, for I am a sinner.’ I tell you, this sinner, not the Pharisee, returned home justified before God. For those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”"
Notice that the Pharisee wasn't thinking that he generated his righteousness through his own strength. He was thanking God for God producing that righteousness in him. This man had God-produced righteousness yet he was not justified. No, it was rather the humble man who went home justified. What does that tell us about God? That he loves trust in his grace more than he loves perfect works. He loves humility. I believe if God had a choice between creating a perfect man or creating a trusting man who sinned, he would choose a trusting man who sinned, because there God's love can abound. If that is offensive I want to let it be offensive. It needs to be. You might say that the Pharisee did have sin in his life and just didn't realize it and that's why God didn't justify him, which is true. But supposedly he was much better off than the tax collector who was well known in Jesus's day to extort people for their money and lie. God preferred the humble extorter to the non-sinning, tithing, passionate leader.
Philippians 3:2-9 "Watch out for those dogs, those people who do evil, those mutilators who say you must be circumcised to be saved. For we who worship by the Spirit of God are the ones who are truly circumcised. We rely on what Christ Jesus has done for us. We put no confidence in human effort, though I could have confidence in my own effort if anyone could. Indeed, if others have reason for confidence in their own efforts, I have even more! I was circumcised when I was eight days old. I am a pure-blooded citizen of Israel and a member of the tribe of Benjamin—a real Hebrew if there ever was one! I was a member of the Pharisees, who demand the strictest obedience to the Jewish law. I was so zealous that I harshly persecuted the church. And as for righteousness, I obeyed the law without fault. I once thought these things were valuable, but now I consider them worthless because of what Christ has done. Yes, everything else is worthless when compared with the infinite value of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have discarded everything else, counting it all as garbage, so that I could gain Christ and become one with him. I no longer count on my own righteousness through obeying the law; rather, I become righteous through faith in Christ. For God’s way of making us right with himself depends on faith."
Maybe this understanding gives us some insight into why Jesus said and did some of the things he did. Maybe he was using the law to humble the prideful and to show them their sins. Let us not make the mistake of trusting in our flesh and "counting" on ourselves to have good behavior. Behavior is a fruit of the gospel, it is not the root. As soon as behavior gets mixed into the foundation of being alright with God, it becomes unstable, just like building the foundation half way on sand and half way on concrete. http://www.desiringgod.org/conference-messages/did-jesus-preach-the-gospel-of-evangelicalism

item.title: Confession 2
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
When Jesus gave himself for us, he wanted to give us confidence and security in our hearts that we were right and at peace with God.
Romans 5:1 "Therefore, since we have been justified through faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ" Hebrews 9:9 "This is an illustration for the present time, indicating that the gifts and sacrifices being offered were not able to clear the conscience of the worshiper." Hebrews 9:14 "The blood of Christ, who had no defect, does even more. Through the eternal Spirit he offered himself to God and cleansed our consciences from the useless things we had done. Now we can serve the living God." Hebrews 4:16 "Let us then approach God's throne of grace with confidence, so that we may receive mercy and find grace to help us in our time of need" Ephesians 3:12 "Because of Christ and our faith in him, we can now come boldly and confidently into God's presence." Hebrews 10:22 "let us draw near to God with a sincere heart and with the full assurance that faith brings, having our hearts sprinkled to cleanse us from a guilty conscience and having our bodies washed with pure water."
Today there is a belief that a believer must confess each of his sins every time he commits them to remain forgiven and accepted by God. This belief varies in how it's practiced. Some say we can confess sins in chunks, however they only receive forgiveness for the chunk they confessed. Others say confession is not necessary for forgiveness but God won't want to be near you until you do confess. Even others suggest that unless you also turn from that behavior and fix yourself your confession means nothing and you are not right with God. Such teachings steal from the confidence and assurance Jesus wanted to give us. I've heard of a few people who would pray that God would not let them die before they had confessed all their sins. They were worried if they died and had some unconfessed sin in their life, they weren't going to go to heaven. Others have taken confession to the point where they could not function properly in public. They would be in the middle of a sports game and would have to confess for having a bad thought. These people took confession seriously. Confession to one another can be useful if we use it properly. It can bring healing and restoration in relationships when we've wronged someone else and can be a tool to help us overcome our sins or guilt by admitting we need help. However, when we make God's acceptance, relationship with us, and forgiveness conditional upon our confession, then instead of bringing life it actually becomes a source of stress and worry.

An intimate reminder of sin

The old testament sacrifices continually reminded us of sin. Every day, 'Hi Bob'. 'Hi Joe, lusted again? Weren't you just in here yesterday? And the day before that?' 'Yep, let's get this sacrifice over with.' Each day you were intimately reminded of how many times you had failed. These sacrifices were temporary, they only covered the sins committed up until that point. Jesus's sacrifice was superior because it only needed to be offered once. How could it be offered only once? Because it also covered future sins. You see, if Jesus's blood was like animals, it would have to be reapplied every time a new sin was committed. But Jesus took away all sin once and for all.
Colossians 3:13 "When you were dead in your sins and in the uncircumcision of your sinful nature, God made you alive with Christ. He forgave us all our sins," Hebrews 10:10 "For God's will was for us to be made holy by the sacrifice of the body of Jesus Christ, once for all time." Hebrews 7:27 "Unlike the other high priests, he does not need to offer sacrifices day after day, first for his own sins, and then for the sins of the people. He sacrificed for their sins once for all when he offered himself." 1 Peter 3:18 "For Christ died for sins once for all, the righteous for the unrighteous, to bring you to God. He was put to death in the body but made alive by the Spirit," Hebrews 9:28 "so also Christ was offered once for all time as a sacrifice to take away the sins of many people."
And since it cleanses forever and doesn't need to keep being redone, we can also have a clear conscience without the intimate reminder of sin every day. Confession acts as an intimate reminder of how often we fail and it causes us to believe for a moment we are unforgiven.

1 John - If we confess our sins...

However 1 John and James talk about confession and so we need to address these passages, one at a time. Daniel Mentz writes a more thorough article on 1 John 1:9. I will summarize the most important points. 1 John was writing to two audiences: gnostics and christians. In the first chapter he primary deals with beliefs that gnostics held and encouraged them to join in true fellowship with other believers.
1 John 1:3 "We proclaim to you what we ourselves have actually seen and heard so that you may have fellowship with us."
Then at the beginning of chapter 2 he begins to address the christians.
1 John 2:1 "My dear children, I am writing this to you so that you will not sin"
Gnosticism was a popular belief around the time of John's letter and held several theological errors that John specifically addresses in chapter 1. One of them being that sin did not matter or exist. The error in this theology is that if sin did not exist then forgiveness was not necessary and they could not be forgiven.
1 John 1:8-9 "If we claim we have no sin, we are only fooling ourselves and not living in the truth. But if we confess our sins to him, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all wickedness."
The first step to becoming a believer is realizing our need for a savior. When we admit that we are sinful and believe in what Jesus did for our sins, God is just and faithful to forgive us all our sins that we will ever commit from that moment on. If we don't admit that we have sins we won't reach out for God's forgiveness.
"cleanse us from all wickedness"
Once you are cleansed from all wickedness, it is not necessary to continue to confess each individual sin, the point was the realization that we had sin at all.

Continuous tense

Some scholars argue that the word confess is in the present continuous tense showing that it is meant to be read "continuously confess," or "are confessing" I am not a Greek scholar and I do not know enough to accurately prove this theory, but I would offer the suggestion that perhaps the reason for this is because it is written to a group of people as a whole. For each new person who comes to Christ he must realize that his sins need forgiveness. For instance,
"If American students keep on passing the ACT exam, we will have a superior education system!" "If we Americans are passing the ACT exam, we are facilitating a superior education system!"
Each person is assumed to pass the exam only once, yet because there are many people we can use the present continuous tense.

2 John addresses Believers

Now lets look at the first verse of the next chapter where he's addressing christians.
1 John 2:1-2 "My dear children, I write this to you so that you will not sin. But if anybody does sin, we have an advocate with the Father—Jesus Christ, the Righteous One. He is the atoning sacrifice for our sins, and not only for ours but also for the sins of the whole world."
He doesn't tell them to confess in order to be forgiven, he tells them, "if anybody does sin, we have an advocate with the Father."

James

Now let's look at the word of confession in James 5.
James 5:13- 16 "Is anyone among you in trouble? Let them pray. Is anyone happy? Let them sing songs of praise. Is anyone among you sick? Let them call the elders of the church to pray over them and anoint them with oil in the name of the Lord. And the prayer offered in faith will make the sick person well; the Lord will raise them up. If they have sinned, they will be forgiven. Therefore confess your sins to each other and pray for each other so that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person is powerful and effective.
I do not completely understand what he is saying but I can make some notes.
  • James does not say unless you confess you cannot be forgiven. He says, "If they have sinned, they will be forgiven."
  • It seems he could be asking us to be vulnerable about where we are so that others can pray for God's healing and deliverance from that sickness or sin and reassure us of God's forgiveness. The sickness and sin do not necessarily need to be connected.
  • Notice that shortly after James talks about helping people come to Christ furthering the case that he may be talking about helping each other turn from sin by admitting our struggles.
James 5:19-20 "My brothers and sisters, if one of you should wander from the truth and someone should bring that person back, remember this: Whoever turns a sinner from the error of their way will save them from death and cover over a multitude of sins."

But confession restores your relationship with God?

Confessing your faults over and over does not bring you closer to God. God has drawn himself near by his own Hand.
2 Corinthians 5:19 "For God was in Christ, reconciling the world to himself, no longer counting people's sins against them. And he gave us this wonderful message of reconciliation"
Your relationship with God is built upon the steady foundation of Christ. Whatever is built upon him will be stable. But if you envision your relationship as built off of your flesh (your ability to confess, show good will, and improve your behavior) your confidence will shake. Even when you do well your confidence will shake, for you do not know when you will fail again. You will be like a wave of the sea, tossed and driven by your latest performance.
Phillippians 3:3 "For we who worship by the Spirit of God are the ones who are truly circumcised. We rely on what Christ Jesus has done for us. We put no confidence in human effort" Jeremiah 17:5 "This is what the LORD says: "Cursed is the one who trusts in man, who draws strength from mere flesh and whose heart turns away from the LORD."
I'm not saying you will be cursed, merely that your flesh is unstable and not suitable to base God's relationship with you on.
Romans 5:9 "Since we have now been justified by his blood, how much more shall we be saved from God's wrath through him!" Isaiah 54:9 "To me this is like the days of Noah, when I swore that the waters of Noah would never again cover the earth. So now I have sworn not to be angry with you, never to rebuke you again"
Jesus's sacrifice adequately covered your sins, so God does not take offense at you and does not require a constant confession for you to maintain forgiveness. Also, if continuous confession is so important to be forgiven, why do none of Paul's letters address it? A great resource for this is, http://jesusgiveslife.blogspot.com/2007/08/1-john-19.html

item.title: Perish or eternal torment - questioning modern ideas of hell
item.dc:creator: jonpaulmiles
item.content:encoded:
A couple years ago I was studying the final day of judgement in Revelations and at one point was deeply saddened by the idea of people being tormented in hell forever. I talked to the Lord about it saying, "Lord, at least let those people die and cease to exist instead of being tormented forever!" That evening I stumbled across a video which actually talked about this subject in a way I had never heard before. The traditional ideas we have about hell have been somewhat foundational in our christian education and at least in my experience have rarely been questioned. In fact, I felt somehow it was wrong to question our traditional view. However, upon further study I realized how misinformed I was about this subject. This is not a subject that is critical to our faith. We who believe in what Jesus did for us are not going to experience hell. However, many atheists are avoiding christianity because of our view of hell and what that says about God. Not to say that we should adopt our gospel because somebody doesn't like it, after all if it is true and the Lord has said it, we must hold to it. However, if you take the journey I went on, you may find that we don't have to hold onto the traditional model of hell and even that our present understanding holds little water. Dozens of well-respected scholars including N T Wright have questioned today's ideas and have found that the Bible doesn't really teach hell that way. We often explain hell as a place of eternal torment where a person's spirit lives forever in pain. However, when a thorough examination of the Bible is made, you will find that the Bible much more so presents the picture of a temporary suffering and end. That is, those people who rejected the free gift of forgiveness through Jesus and lived their lives doing evil are sentenced to their torment and finally destroyed on the day of judgement. Not living forever, but completely dead, soul and body.
Matthew 10:28 "Do not fear those who kill the body but are unable to kill the soul; but rather fear Him who is able to destroy both soul and body in hell." John 3:16 "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life." Ecclesiastes 9:10 "Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your might; for there is no activity or planning or knowledge or wisdom in Sheol..." (Sheol and Hades are different translations of the same word. Sometimes hell is translated from the same word.)
People who refuse to believe do not have eternal life in torment, they completely perish, soul and body. This video which is an hour long, goes through the Bible, from the old testament to the new and explains some of the difficult scriptures and enforces this perspective.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHUPpmbTOV4
This video however does not cover well one particular parable about the rich man and lazarus. For that I have a scholarly article.
http://www.truthaccordingtoscripture.com/documents/death/the-rich-man-and-lazarus-dawson.php#.VKRFAYrF_xE
This parable was actually a spin on a popular story that was told in that day. It originated with pagans possibly from Egypt or Greece and spread to Jews. The point of the parable was not to show us what happened in the after life, but to show us how God felt about the current condition of the unfaithful Jews. The original story was told almost same way, however instead it was the rich man who was in Abraham's bosom and it was the poor man who was in hell. This was because the Jews saw riches as a sign of God's favor. You can see this in the story of Job and in the blessings given for keeping the law. It was perceived that those who were poor had sinned and offended God and the rich were favored. Jesus was using this story to point to the behavior of the unfaithful Jews who had been entrusted with the instructions of God and the favor of God, but had not shared that light with the Gentiles. As such those unfaithful Jews would be shut out of the kingdom while the Gentiles would be invited in because they believed while the unfaithful Jews killed their Messiah. Jesus was not saying that their idea of hell was correct but instead he was revealing a faulty understanding of riches using their own story as a way to explain.
It must also be remembered that this is only a parable, and not a real history; for, as Dr. Whitby affirms, "we find this very parable in the Gemara Babylonicum." The story was not new, then, not original with Christ, but known among the Jews before He repeated it. He borrowed the parable from them, and employed it to show the judgment which awaited them. He represented the spiritual favors and privileges of the Jews by the wealth and luxury of the rich man, and the spiritual poverty of the Gentiles by the beggary and infirmity of Lazarus; and while the former would be deprived of their privileges and punished for their wickedness, the latter would enjoy the blessings of truth and faith. The Jews accepted this picture of Abraham's bosom very much like many Christians accept the idea that the Apostle Peter supposedly sits at the Heavenly Pearly Gates, with the ledger of the faithful dead, and the keys of admission to bid them enter. (Thomas B. Thayer, The Origin & History of the Doctrine of Endless Punishment [Boston: Universalist Publishing House, 1855], p. 57.)
I hope this evidence is thought provoking and encourages us to learn more.
